What is the function of cranial nerve 1?: Cranial nerve 1, also known as the olfactory nerve, is responsible for the sense of smell.

What is the function of the optic nerve: The function of the optic nerve is to transmit visual information from the retina to the brain.
What are the functions of the oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling the movements of the eyes. It innervates four of the six extraocular muscles that control eye movement, as well as the intrinsic eye muscles that control pupil constriction and accommodation.
What are the functions of the trochlear: The trochlear nerve, also known as cranial nerve IV, is a motor nerve that sends signals from the brain to the superior oblique muscle in the eye. It controls eye movement, particularly looking down.
What are the functions of the trigeminal: The trigeminal nerve, also known as the fifth cranial nerve, has both sensory and motor functions. What are the functions of the abducens n: The abducens nerve is a cranial nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for the abduction of the eye. What are the functions of the facial ner: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) has motor, sensory, and parasympathetic functions. What are the functions of the vestibuloc: The vestibulocochlear nerve, also known as cranial nerve VIII, plays a critical role in two primary functions: hearing and balance. What are the functions if the glossophar: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) has several functions, including sensory input from the tonsils and pharynx, motor control of the stylopharyngeus muscle, and salivation.
What are the functions of the vagus nerv: The vagus nerve, also known as the parasympathetic nervous system, plays a crucial role in regulating involuntary body functions such as digestion, heart rate, and immune response. What are the functions of the accessory: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) primarily provides motor innervation to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles in the neck and shoulder region. It also contributes to the movement of the pharynx and larynx.
What are the functions of the hypoglossa: The hypoglossal nerve, also known as the twelfth cranial nerve (CN XII), innervates all the extrinsic and intrinsic muscles of the tongue, except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve. It plays a crucial role in speech, swallowing, and chewing.

Where are the cell bodies of the parasym: The cell bodies of parasympathetic preganglionic neurons are located in the brainstem and in the sacral spinal cord.

What is the difference between somatic m: The main difference between somatic motor and autonomic outflow is that the somatic nervous system controls voluntary movements, while the autonomic nervous system regulates involuntary functions such as heart rate, digestion, and bowel movements.

What are the 3 subdivisions of the White: The three main subdivisions of white matter are the commissural fibers, association fibers, and projection fibers.
What tracts are present in the posterior: The tracts present in the posterior funiculus are the gracilis and cuneate fasciculi, also known as the posterior spinocerebellar tract. These are ascending pathways that carry fine and discriminative touch as well as proprioceptive sensations.
What tracts are present in the antero-la: The anterolateral regions of the white matter contain the anterior spinothalamic tract and the lateral spinothalamic tract. What are the pathways important in contr: The pathways important in controlling the trunk include the anterior corticospinal tract, the posterior corticospinal tract, and the parasympathetic nervous system. What is motor neurons disease ?: Motor neuron disease (MND) is a group of neurodegenerative disorders characterized by the progressive degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscles. What are the symptoms of motor neurons d: The symptoms of motor neuron disease (MND) can vary depending on the specific type of the disease. What does the hindbrain include ?: The hindbrain includes the medulla oblongata, pons, and cerebellum.
What is the BRAINSTEM ?: The brainstem is the posterior stalk-like part of the brain that connects the cerebrum with the spinal cord. It is composed of three main parts: the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata, each playing a crucial role in regulating several involuntary actions of the body, such as breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure.
What is the trigeminal system ?: The trigeminal system refers to the fifth cranial nerve, which is the largest and most complex of the 12 cranial nerves. It has both sensory and motor functions, providing sensation to the face and controlling the muscles of mastication. The trigeminal nerve has three main branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) nerves.
What is pyramidal decussation ?: Pyramidal decussation is the point in the medulla oblongata where the nerve fibers from the motor cortex of one side of the brain cross to the opposite side of the body. This crossing allows for the brain's motor signals to control movements on the contralateral (opposite) side of the body, forming the lateral corticospinal tract in the spinal cord.
What can be seen on the dorsal surface o: On the dorsal surface of the brainstem, there are four rounded structures known as the colliculi, which are involved in visual and auditory processing.
What can be viewed on the ventral surfac: The ventral surface of the brainstem includes structures such as the midbrain, pons, and medulla. The oculomotor nerve (CN III) and trigeminal nerve (CN V) emerge from the ventral surface of the brainstem.
What are the somatic motor nucleus\u2019: The somatic motor nuclei in the brainstem are responsible for controlling the movement of skeletal muscles. These nuclei are located in the medulla oblongata, pons, and diencephalon.
What are the general sensory nuclei foun: The general sensory nuclei found in the brainstem are the mesencephalic nucleus, principal sensory nucleus, and spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
What special sensory nuclei are found in: There are several special sensory nuclei found in the brainstem, including the nucleus solitarius, which is responsible for controlling the vagus nerve and other autonomic functions.
What are the visceral motor nuclei found: The visceral motor nuclei found in the brainstem include the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus, the nucleus ambiguus, and the nucleus solitarius. These nuclei are involved in controlling involuntary functions such as heart rate, digestion, and respiration.
What visceral sensory nuclei are found i: There are several visceral sensory nuclei found in the brainstem, including the nucleus solitarius, which is located in the medulla oblongata.
What are the brachial motor nuclei found: The brachial motor nuclei are found in the brainstem tegmentum. These nuclei are responsible for innervating muscles derived from the branchial arches, which are involved in functions such as facial expression and swallowing.
What happens at the caudal medulla ?: The caudal medulla is the most caudal part of the medulla oblongata, which is the terminal part of the brainstem. It connects the brainstem to the spinal cord and regulates vital functions such as blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration. It also contains the origins of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII, and motor neurons cross from the left motor cortex to the caudal medulla.
What is wallenbergs syndrome ?: Wallenberg syndrome, also known as lateral medullary syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a stroke in the lateral medulla of the brain stem. It is characterized by a range of symptoms, including impaired coordination, balance, and swallowing problems. The syndrome is named after Adolf Wallenberg, who first described it in 1895.
What are BRAINSTEM gliomas ?: Brainstem gliomas are tumors that grow in the brainstem, which connects the lower part of the brain to the top of the spinal cord.
What are the functions of the reticular: The reticular formation is a complex network of neurons in the brainstem that plays a crucial role in regulating the sleep-wake cycle and maintaining alertness. It also serves as a major integration and relay center for various brain systems, coordinating autonomic, motor, sensory, and cognitive functions.
What are the 3 nuclei of the raphe nucle: The three nuclei of the raphe nucleus are the raphe magnus nucleus (RMg), the raphe obscurus nucleus (ROb), and the raphe pallidus nucleus (RPa).
What arthe functions of the raphe nucleu: The raphe nucleus is a cluster of nuclei located in the brainstem, primarily containing serotonergic neurons. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in mood regulation, sleep-wake cycle regulation, and other cognitive and behavioral processes.
Explain the somatic nervous system ?: The somatic nervous system (SNS) is a part of the peripheral nervous system responsible for controlling voluntary movements and transmitting sensory information from the external environment to the central nervous system. It consists of motor neurons that control skeletal muscles and sensory neurons that relay information from sensory receptors in the skin and other parts of the body. The SNS enables conscious control over muscle contractions and processes sensory input related to touch, pain, temperature, and proprioception.
How much does the human brain weigh ?: The average human brain weighs approximately 1.5 kilograms or 3.3 pounds.
Explain the autonomic nervous system: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) is a part of the nervous system that regulates involuntary bodily functions such as heart rate, digestion, and breathing. It consists of two main branches: the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system. The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for preparing the body for stress or emergencies, while the parasympathetic nervous system promotes relaxation and rest. Both systems work together to maintain the body's internal balance and homeostasis.
What does the brain and spinal cord orig: The brain and spinal cord originate from the neural tube during embryonic development.
What is neurulation ?: Neurulation is the process of folding and fusion of the neural plate into the neural tube, which eventually develops into the central nervous system (CNS). This process occurs in two phases: primary neurulation and secondary neurulation.
What does the mesoderm form around the n: The mesoderm forms around the neural tube during embryonic development. It is responsible for the formation of the spinal cord, skeletal system, and organs such as the liver, kidney, and pancreas.
What is the forebrain divided into ?: The forebrain is divided into four lobes: the frontal lobe, parietal lobe, temporal lobe, and occipital lobe.
What is the midbrain (mesencephalon) div: The midbrain (mesencephalon) is divided into two main parts: the cerebral peduncles and the tectum and tegmentum. The cerebral peduncles are bundles of nerve fibers that connect the midbrain to the cerebral cortex, while the tectum and tegmentum are bundles of nerve fibers that connect the midbrain to the spinal cord.
What is the hindbrain (rhombencephalon): The hindbrain (rhombencephalon) is divided into three main areas: the cerebellum, pons, and medulla oblongata.
What is the small core of the mesencepha: The small core of the mesencephalon is the tegmentum.
How is the cerebellum formed ?: The cerebellum is formed during embryonic development from neural progenitor cells called granule cells. These granule cells migrate from the rhombic lip to the flocculonodular granule layer (EGL) and then to the internal granule layer (IGL). This process is regulated by various signaling pathways, including Sonic hedgehog signaling, which can also predispose to conditions like medulloblastoma if abnormally activated.
What is the function of the cerebrum ?: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is responsible for a wide range of functions, including motor control, sensory processing, decision-making, and higher cognitive processes.
What is the function of the cerebellum ?: The cerebellum is a part of the brain that plays a critical role in motor control and coordination. It is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and muscle control. It also plays a role in motor learning and memory. Damage to the cerebellum can lead to ataxia, which is characterized by a loss of muscle control and coordination.
What is the function of the brainstorm ?: The function of a brainstorm is to generate a large number of ideas or solutions to a problem or challenge.
What is the function of the hippocampus: The hippocampus is a small, curved formation located deep in the temporal lobe of the brain. It has three primary functions: forming new memories, learning, and emotions. It plays a crucial role in consolidating information from short-term memory to long-term memory.
What is the function of the pituitary gl: The pituitary gland is a part of the endocrine system and releases hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, and adrenocorticotrophin (ACTH). It also plays a role in controlling other endocrine glands, such as the thyroid and sex organs.
What is the function of the hypothalamus: The hypothalamus is a part of the brain that regulates various bodily functions such as hunger, thirst, body temperature, blood pressure, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a role in controlling emotions and behavior.
What is chemical transmission ?: Chemical transmission refers to the process by which neurotransmitters, such as dopamine and serotonin, are released from presynaptic neurons and bind to receptors on postsynaptic neurons. This process is called synaptic transmission and is the primary mode of communication in the nervous system.
What is electrical transmission ?: Electrical transmission is the process of delivering generated electricity over long distances to the distribution grid in populated areas. This involves the use of transformers to increase voltage levels, making long-distance transmission feasible. The system includes power plants, substations, and interconnected lines that facilitate the bulk movement of electrical energy from generation sites to load centers.
What are the similarities of chemical an: Both chemical and electrical transmissions involve the transmission of signals between neurons through the use of neurotransmitters and gap junctions. However, the main difference between the two is the mode of transmission. Chemical synapses use neurotransmitters to transmit a signal, while electrical synapses use ion channels to transmit a signal.
What are the criteria for a chemical mes: The criteria for a chemical messenger to be considered a neurotransmitter are that it must be synthesized and stored in the presynaptic neuron, be released in response to an action potential, bind to specific receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, and be removed from the synaptic cleft to terminate its action.
What are the molecule involved in vesicl: The molecules involved in vesicle release include SNARE proteins (such as Syntaxin-1, Synaptobrevin, and SNAP-25), which facilitate the fusion of vesicles with the plasma membrane. When an action potential triggers a Ca2+ influx into the presynaptic terminal, it initiates a series of priming reactions that prepare the vesicles for rapid release. This process allows for the release of neurotransmitters and other signaling molecules, enabling communication between cells.
What are metabotropic receptors ?: Metabotropic receptors are a class of G-protein-coupled receptors that mediate the effects of various peptide and non-peptide neurotransmitters and neuromodulators. They are responsible for slow synaptic transmission and mediate the effects of hundreds of peptide and non-peptide neurotransmitters and neuromodulators.
What are ionotropic receptors ?: Ionotropic receptors are fast-acting, ligand-gated ion channels that open in response to the binding of neurotransmitters, allowing ions to flow into or out of the cell. They contain two functional domains: an extracellular site that binds neurotransmitters and a membrane-spanning domain that forms the ion channel. The three main types of ionotropic receptors are NMDA, AMPA, and kainate receptors, which play crucial roles in synaptic transmission and plasticity.
What are gray\u2019s type 1 synapses?: Gray's Type 1 synapses, also known as asymmetric synapses, are excitatory synapses that are characterized by a thick postsynaptic density. They are primarily found in the cerebral cortex and are important for regulating neuronal activity and plasticity.
What are gray\u2019s type 2 synapses ?: Gray's Type 2 synapses, also known as symmetric synapses, are inhibitory synapses that are characterized by asymmetric pre- and postsynaptic densities. They are associated with the neurotransmitter -aminobutyric acid (GABA) and play a crucial role in balancing excitatory and inhibitory signals in the central nervous system.
What are axo-dendritic synapses ?: Axo-dendritic synapses are a type of synapses where the axon of one neuron connects to the dendrite of another neuron.
What are axo-somatic synapses ?: Axo-somatic synapses are synapses where the presynaptic axon terminal connects to the soma (cell body) of the postsynaptic neuron.
What are axo-axonic synapses ?: Axo-axonic synapses are specialized synapses where one axon terminates on another axon or axon terminal. These synapses are found in various parts of the nervous system, including the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nervous system.
What is temporal summation ?: Temporal summation refers to the additive effect of several electrical impulses on a neuromuscular junction. It occurs when one presynaptic neuron releases neurotransmitters over a period of time to fire an action potential. Temporal summation is a clinical measure of central sensitization, indicating that successive stimuli can generate a response when individual stimuli cannot. It differs from spatial summation, where multiple presynaptic neurons release neurotransmitters simultaneously to trigger an action potential.
What is spatial summation ?: Spatial summation is a mechanism by which synaptic potentials generated at different sites combine to produce a larger overall effect. It occurs when multiple presynaptic neurons are activated simultaneously, leading to sufficient neurotransmitter release to trigger an action potential in the postsynaptic neuron. This process is influenced by the spatial constant, the ability of a potential change produced in one region of a cell to spread passively to other regions of a cell.
Which structures of the brain connect th: The structures of the brain that connect the cerebral hemispheres are the corpus callosum and the cerebral sulcus.
How many neurons are present in human ce: The human cerebral cortex contains approximately 16 billion neurons.
What is the function of the precentral g: The precentral gyrus, also known as the primary motor cortex, is responsible for controlling voluntary movements of the body. It is located in the frontal lobe and contains large pyramidal neurons called Betz cells that send long axons to the contralateral motor nuclei of the cranial nerves and to the lower motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.
What is the function of the post central: The postcentral gyrus is a gyrus in the lateral parietal lobe of the human brain, primarily responsible for processing somatosensory information from the body. It contains the primary somatosensory cortex, which is responsible for processing various somatic sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and pain.
What is Brodmann areas ?: Brodmann areas are regions of the cerebral cortex defined by their distinct cytoarchitecture, or histological structure and organization of cells. They were first mapped by Korbinian Brodmann in the early 20th century and are used to identify specific functional areas of the brain, such as those involved in sensory processing, motor control, and higher cognitive functions.
Which laminae are important for sensory: The laminae that are important for sensory input are the dorsal horn laminae. These laminae are responsible for receiving and processing sensory input from the peripheral nervous system.
What laminae is important for motor inpu: Lamina VI is important for motor input as it contains interneurons that are involved in the modulation of spinal reflexes and proprioception.
What are some of the key areas of the su: Some of the key areas of the subdivisions of the cerebral cortex include the primary motor cortex, the primary somatosensory cortex, the primary visual cortex, the primary auditory cortex, and the Broca's area, which is involved in language production.
What do the layers if the cerebral corte: The cerebral cortex has six distinct layers, numbered from the outermost layer (Layer 1) to the innermost layer (Layer 6). Each layer is differentiated by the size and shape of the neuronal cell bodies and axon terminals. Layer 1 is the molecular layer, containing few neuronal cell bodies but many dendrites and axons. Layer 2 is the external granular layer, containing small pyramidal neurons and numerous small granule cells.
What are basket cells like ?: Basket cells are inhibitory interneurons found in the neocortex, cerebellum, and hippocampus. They are characterized by their axonal arborizations that form 'baskets' around the somata of target neurons. They are primarily parvalbumin-expressing and fast-spiking, playing a crucial role in maintaining the balance of excitation and inhibition within cortical networks.
What are EEGs and explain the different: EEGs (Electroencephalograms) are tests that detect and record the electrical activity of the brain through electrodes placed on the scalp. The different types of brain waves detected by EEG include delta waves (0-4 Hz), theta waves (4-8 Hz), alpha waves (8-13 Hz), and beta waves (13-30 Hz). Each wave type reflects varying levels of brain activity and can indicate different states of consciousness or neurological conditions.
What is CT imaging ?: CT imaging, or computed tomography imaging, is a medical imaging technique that uses X-rays to produce detailed cross-sectional images of internal organs, bones, and soft tissues.
What is MRI imaging ?: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a non-invasive medical imaging technique that uses a powerful magnetic field, radio waves, and a computer to produce detailed images of the internal structures of the body. It is particularly useful for evaluating soft tissues such as the brain, spinal cord, and joints, as well as for diagnosing conditions such as cancer, heart disease, and stroke.
What is PET pane fMRI imaging ?: PET pane fMRI imaging is a combination of positron emission tomography (PET) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) that allows for the simultaneous imaging of both metabolic and functional changes in the brain. This allows for a more comprehensive assessment of brain function and disease progression.
How much of the cerebral cortex is made: The association cortex is a part of the cerebral cortex that is involved in higher-order cognitive functions such as perception, language, and decision-making. It is located in the frontal lobe and is responsible for integrating information from various sensory modalities and supporting higher-order cognitive processes such as language, perception, and decision-making.
What is the flow of connections of corti: The flow of connections of cortical areas involves a complex network of interconnected regions of the brain that process and transmit neural signals. These connections are anatomical, but also involve neurotransmitters, hormones, and other neuromodulators that control the flow of neural activity. Understanding the flow of connections among cortical areas is a key aspect of understanding how the brain functions and how it can be manipulated for therapeutic purposes.
What is contra lateral neglect syndrome: Contralateral neglect syndrome, also known as unilateral spatial neglect or hemineglect, is a condition where individuals fail to respond to or acknowledge stimuli on the contralateral side of a brain lesion, despite having intact sensory and motor functions. This condition is commonly seen in patients who have suffered a right hemisphere stroke.
What is prospognosia?: Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is a condition where a person struggles to recognize faces or can't interpret facial expressions and cues.
What are the symptoms of Broca\u2019s ap: Symptoms of Broca's aphasia include poor or absent grammar, difficulty forming complete sentences, and the omission of small linking words such as 'the', 'an', and 'and'.
What are the effects of wernickes aphasi: Wernicke's aphasia is caused by damage to the Wernicke's area of the brain, which is responsible for processing language. It is characterized by impaired language comprehension, meaning that individuals with Wernicke's aphasia have difficulty understanding spoken words and sentences. While individuals with Wernicke's aphasia can produce fluent and grammatically correct speech, their sentences may contain irrelevant words or incorrect sounds, leading to a lack of meaningful communication.
Explain bilingualism ?: Bilingualism is the ability to speak and use two or more languages effectively. It can be acquired early in life, often through exposure to two or more languages in a family, school, or community. It can also be acquired through immersion in a bilingual or multilingual environment, or through language acquisition through immersion programs or language immersion programs.
What is \u201csplit brain\u201d and what: Split brain refers to a condition where the corpus callosum, the bridge of nerve fibers connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, is severed. It is used to treat intractable epilepsy.
Where is language specialisation mainly: Language specialization is mainly in the left hemisphere of the brain, particularly in the frontal and temporal lobes. This includes areas such as Broca's area, which is involved in speech production, and Wernicke's area, which is involved in language comprehension.
What do the alar plates give rise to ?: The alar plates give rise to the dorsal gray matter of the spinal cord, as well as the sensory nuclei of cranial nerves V, VII, VIII, IX, and X.
What is the midbrain important for and w: The midbrain is important for various functions such as motor control, sensory perception, and sleep-wake cycle regulation. During development, the size of the optic tectum, which is involved in visual processing, reduces.
What do the basal plates give rise to ?: The basal plates give rise to motor neurons and other structures of the ventral part of the spinal cord.
What is the overall function of the ocul: The oculomotor nucleus, located in the midbrain, controls the muscles responsible for eye movements. It consists of subnuclei that innervate specific eye muscles, such as the medial rectus and inferior oblique, and also plays a role in innervating the levator muscles.
What is the overall function of the edin: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is primarily responsible for controlling the pupillary reflex and accommodation. It also plays a role in stress response and emotional regulation.
Where does the tectum lie ?: The tectum is located on the roof of the midbrain and contains the superior and inferior colliculi, which are responsible for visual and auditory reflexes, respectively.
Where does the tegmentum lie ?: The tegmentum lies dorsal to the base and ventral to the cerebral aqueduct or fourth ventricle.
Where are the basis pedunculi and what d: The basis pedunculi are located in the midbrain, covering the anterolateral portions of the brainstem. They contain the crura cerebri and the substantia nigra, which are involved in motor control and contain large nerve fiber tracts.
On the ventral surface what are the limi: The ventral surface of the midbrain is marked by the cerebral peduncles, which are two stalks that extend from the thalamus to the pons.
What are the main cranial nerves in the: The main cranial nerves in the midbrain are the oculomotor nerve (III) and the trochlear nerve (IV).
Which surface of the brain is the midbra: The midbrain is more clear on the ventral (anterior) surface of the brain.
What are the limits of the midbrain on t: The limits of the midbrain on the dorsal surface are defined by the tectum, which includes the superior and inferior colliculi.
What inputs does the superior colliculus: The superior colliculus receives inputs from various sensory modalities, including visual, auditory, and somatosensory inputs. It also receives inhibitory inputs from the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus.
What nucleus does the superior colliculu: The superior colliculus (SC) feeds information to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and the basal ganglia. The motor response produced by the SC is primarily related to eye movements, such as saccades.
What happens if you have a lesion throug: If you have a lesion through the superior colliculus, you may experience difficulties in orienting your head and eyes, as well as impaired visuospatial attention and perceptual decision-making.
Where does the inferior colliculus recei: The inferior colliculus receives auditory information from the lower auditory brainstem and sends auditory information to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.
What is the inferior colliculus importan: The inferior colliculus is important for auditory processing, serving as a relay point for sound information as it travels from the inner ear to the auditory cortex. It processes sound frequency, intensity, and temporal patterns, and aids in sound localization.
Why is the red nucleus highly pigmented: The red nucleus is highly pigmented due to the presence of hemoglobin and ferritin, which are iron-containing proteins.
The red nucleus is a motor nucleus assoc: The red nucleus is a motor nucleus associated with the midbrain.
Which tract originates in the red nucleu: The rubrospinal tract originates in the red nucleus and is involved in controlling muscle tone in flexor muscle groups.
What are the 2 outputs of the red nucleu: The two outputs of the red nucleus are the rubrospinal tract and the inferior olivary complex. The rubrospinal tract projects to the cervical region of the spinal cord, while the inferior olivary complex projects to the cerebellum.
How is cerebellum ataxia caused ?: Cerebellum ataxia can be caused by a variety of factors, including damage to the cerebellum itself, damage to its connections, or a combination of both. Some common causes of cerebellar ataxia include stroke, traumatic brain injury, and neurodegenerative conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.
Which main structure of the midbrain is: The anterior midbrain consists of the cerebral peduncles, while the posterior midbrain consists of the tectum and tegmentum. So, the main structure present on the anterior midbrain is the cerebral peduncles, while the main structure present on the posterior midbrain is the tectum and tegmentum.
What does the midbrain locomotor area do: The midbrain locomotor area (MLR) plays a crucial role in controlling posture and gait. It is located in the precentral gyrus and medial prefrontal cortex, and is responsible for integrating sensory inputs from the environment and motor outputs from the spinal cord.
What is the PAG important for ?: The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is important for the modulation of pain, sympathetic responses, and the learning and action of defensive and aversive behaviors.
What are the 2 components of the oculomo: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) has two components: outer parasympathetic fibers and inner somatic fibers. The outer parasympathetic fibers innervate the ciliary muscles and the sphincter pupillae, while the inner somatic fibers innervate the levator palpebrae superioris and the four extraocular muscles (superior, middle, inferior recti, and inferior oblique).
What does the medial longitudinal fasicu: The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is a bundle of nerve fibers in the brainstem that plays a crucial role in coordinating eye movements with head movements. It consists of two main components: the vestibular component, which sends efferents from the vestibular nuclei to the nuclei controlling eye and cervical muscles, and the interneuclear component, which links motor cranial nerve nuclei. This coordination is essential for maintaining balance and proper visual tracking during movement.
What does the trochlear nerve do ?: The trochlear nerve, also known as cranial nerve IV, is a motor nerve that sends signals from the brain to the superior oblique muscle of the eye, enabling downward eye movement. It is the smallest cranial nerve and has the longest intracranial course, originating in the midbrain and extending laterally and anteriorly to the superior oblique muscle.
What happens to the eyes of a lesion or: When a lesion or damage occurs to the trochlear nerve, it can cause problems with eye movement and vision. This can include double vision (diplopia) and difficulty looking downward. Treatment options may include surgery to realign the eyes or medication.
Which region of the brain is the abducen: The abducens nerve is present in the brainstem, specifically at the junction of the pons and the medulla.
What muscle does the abducens nerve cont: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
Cranial nerves 3,4 and 6 completely cont: Cranial nerve 3 (oculomotor nerve) controls the superior, inferior, medial, and inferior recti muscles. Cranial nerve 4 (trochlear nerve) controls the superior oblique muscle. Cranial nerve 6 (abducens nerve) controls the lateral rectus muscle.
Which nerve controls the construction of: The construction of the pupil is controlled by the oculomotor nerve, also known as cranial nerve 3.
What is the direct light reflex ?: The direct light reflex is the constriction of the pupil in response to light shone directly into the eye. It is mediated by the pretectal olivary nucleus, the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, the ciliary ganglia, and the oculomotor nerve.
What is the consensual light reflex ?: The consensual light reflex is a phenomenon where both pupils constrict when light is shone into one eye, even if the other eye is not directly exposed to light. This reflex is mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system and involves the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the short ciliary nerve.
Why is the substantia nigra dark in colo: The substantia nigra is dark in color due to the presence of a pigment called neuromelanin. Neuromelanin is found in high concentrations in the dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra, giving it a dark appearance.
Where does the substantia nigra project: The substantia nigra projects primarily to the striatum, which includes the caudate nucleus and putamen.
Where does the ventral tegmental area pr: The ventral tegmental area (VTA) projects to several brain regions, including the nucleus accumbens, prefrontal cortex, amygdala, and hippocampus.
What is Benedict\u2019s syndrome ?: Benedict's syndrome, also known as red nucleus syndrome or paramedian midbrain syndrome, is a rare neurological condition characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and contralateral cerebellar ataxia.
If dopaminergic systems are damaged diff: If dopaminergic systems are damaged, different disorders can occur. The substantia nigra and striatum are affected in Parkinson's disease, while the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and striatum are affected in depression. Additionally, the VTA and frontal cortex are also affected in depression.
What is part of the diencephalon ?: The diencephalon is a region of the brain that forms part of the forebrain and includes structures such as the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus, and subthalamus.
What is the diencephalon important for ?: The diencephalon is important for a variety of functions, including processing sensory and motor information, regulating autonomic functions, and controlling emotions and memories.
Describe the anterior nuclear group of t: The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is a group of nuclei located in the rostral part of the thalamus. These nuclei receive afferents from the mammillary bodies via the mammillothalamic tract (MTT) and from the subiculum via the fornix. The anterior nuclei are involved in a variety of functions, including attention, memory, and spatial navigation.
Describe the ventral posterior nucleus o: The ventral posterior nucleus (VPN) is a somatosensory relay nucleus in the thalamus of the brain. It receives input from the medial lemniscus, spinothalamic, and trigeminothalamic tracts, and relays this information to the somatosensory cortex and other areas of the brain. The VPN is divided into two subnuclei: the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) and the ventral posteromedial nucleus (VPM).
Describe the lateral geniculate nucleus: The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) is a layered structure in the thalamus that serves as the primary relay center for visual information being transmitted from the retina to the brain. It is organized into distinct layers that process and sort visual inputs, playing a crucial role in visual perception. The LGN has extensive connections to various regions of the extrastriate cortex and plays a crucial role in normal visual processing.
Describe the medial geniculate nucleus o: The medial geniculate nucleus (MGN) is a nucleus in the thalamus that plays a crucial role in the auditory pathway. It receives input from the inferior colliculus and transmits it to the primary auditory cortex. The MGN is organized tonotopically, meaning that different frequencies of sound are represented in specific areas within the nucleus.
Describe the ventral anterior nucleus of: The ventral anterior nucleus (VA) is a nucleus in the thalamus that receives inputs from the basal ganglia and plays a role in modulating these signals. It receives inputs from the globus pallidus and substantia nigra pars reticulata. The VA/VL complex, which includes both the VA and the VL nucleus, is involved in various functions including motor control, attention, and reward processing.
What are the 3 subdivisions of the ventr: The three subdivisions of the ventral lateral nucleus are the ventral anterior nucleus, the ventral posterior nucleus, and the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus.
What is the epithalamus important for ?: The epithalamus is important for regulating circadian rhythms, sleep-wake cycles, and hormonal secretions. It also plays a role in energy conservation and emotional regulation.
What is the reticular nucleus important: The reticular nucleus is important for regulating sleep-wake cycles, attention, and executive function. It contains GABAergic neurons that are involved in these processes. Dysfunction in the reticular nucleus can lead to attention deficit disorders, sleep disturbances, and other neurodevelopmental disorders.
What is the subthalamic nucleus importan: The subthalamic nucleus is important for motor control and the suppression of unwanted movements.
What are the functions of the medial hyp: The medial hypothalamus plays a crucial role in regulating various bodily functions such as appetite, sleep, and body temperature. It is also involved in the regulation of hormones and neurotransmitters.
What are the functions of the lateral hy: The lateral hypothalamus has several functions, including regulation of appetite, thermoregulation, and arousal. It also plays a role in pain perception and nociception through the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve.
What hormone does the paraventricular nu: The paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus releases corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH).
What hormone does the supra optic nucleu: The supraoptic nucleus releases vasopressin, also known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
Where is the diencephalon situated ?: The diencephalon is situated in the midbrain, located between the cerebrum and the brain stem. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus, and subthalamus.
Which ascending pathway is the diencepha: The diencephalon is not involved with any ascending pathway.
The thalamus receives lots of sensory in: The thalamus receives sensory information from various sensory organs such as the auditory, visual, and olfactory systems. The nuclei in the thalamus process and integrate this information before sending it to the cerebral cortex.
What is equilibrium potential for an ion: The equilibrium potential for an ion is the membrane potential at which the concentration gradient and the electrical gradient for that ion are equal and opposite, resulting in no net movement of the ion across the membrane. It can be calculated using the Nernst equation, which takes into account the valence and concentration gradient of the ion.
What happens when ions cross a membrane: When ions cross a membrane to move down their concentration gradient, they do so through a process called facilitated diffusion or passive transport. This process involves specific membrane proteins that form channels or pores, allowing ions to move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration without the expenditure of energy. For example, sodium ions move down their concentration gradient through sodium channels, while potassium ions move down their concentration gradient through potassium channels.
What is an electrochemical potential ?: An electrochemical potential is a measure of the difference in energy of the outermost electrons of a molecule or element in its two valence states. It represents the mechanical work done in bringing 1 mole of an ion from a standard state to a specified concentration and electrical potential.
What does the sodium-potassium ATPase pu: The sodium-potassium ATPase pump, also known as Na+/K+-ATPase, is a transmembrane protein that transports three sodium ions out of the cell for every two potassium ions brought into the cell, against the electrochemical gradient. This process requires ATP (adenosine triphosphate) energy and is essential for various cellular functions, including maintaining osmotic equilibrium, maintaining membrane potential, and regulating cell growth and differentiation.
What are ion channels ?: Ion channels are specialized proteins located in the plasma membrane that allow charged ions to pass through, facilitating their movement down their electrochemical gradient. They play a crucial role in various cellular functions, including the generation of action potentials in neurons and synaptic communication between neurons.
What are transporters/exchangers ?: Transporters/exchangers are membrane proteins that facilitate the movement of solutes, ions, and metabolites across cell membranes. They include single-solute carriers, coupled exchangers, and multi-solute carriers.
What are ion pumps ?: Ion pumps are biological machines that actively transport ions across a membrane against a concentration gradient. They play a crucial role in regulating various biological processes such as maintaining electrolyte balance, generating electrical signals, and regulating cell volume.
How do voltage gated channels ?: Voltage-gated channels are integral membrane proteins that open or close in response to changes in membrane potential. They are ion-specific, with channels for sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl ) ions. These channels are crucial for generating action potentials in neurons, with different types (sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride) playing distinct roles in this process.
Explain the potassium channel selectivit: The potassium channel selectivity filter is a narrow passageway located in the top third of the protein toward the extracellular leaflet of the membrane. This filter allows the channel to discriminate between ions, specifically conducting potassium ions (K+) while excluding other ions, such as sodium (Na+). This selectivity is primarily due to the highly conserved GYG amino acid sequence within the filter, which stabilizes the K+ ion in a specific coordinated state. The filter's structure enables potassium channels to function rapidly and efficiently, playing a crucial role in setting the rest
What are the 2 gates present in sodium c: The two gates present in sodium channels are the activation gate and the inactivation gate. The activation gate opens when the membrane potential reaches approximately -55 mV, allowing sodium ions to flow into the cell. The inactivation gate closes after a specific period of time, stopping the flow of sodium ions. These gates work in tandem to ensure that depolarization occurs in a controlled manner.
What is the voltage-clamp technique ?: The voltage-clamp technique is an electrophysiological method used to measure ion currents across a cell membrane. It involves clamping the membrane potential at a specific level and recording the resulting ion currents.
What does the voltage clamp technique in: The voltage clamp technique is an electrophysiological method used to measure ion currents across a cell membrane. It involves controlling the membrane potential and measuring the resulting ion currents. This technique allows researchers to study voltage-gated ion channels and their function by controlling the membrane potential and observing the resulting ion currents.
What are reversal potentials ?: Reversal potentials are the membrane potentials at which the direction of ionic current through a channel is reversed, meaning there is no net flow of ions across the membrane.
What is the current clamp technique ?: The current clamp technique is a method used to measure the voltage difference across a cellular membrane while injecting a controlled current into the cell. It is commonly used in neuroscience and physiology to study the function of ion channels and other membrane proteins.
When an action potential occurs why does: When an action potential occurs, the membrane potential does not reach the equilibrium potential of sodium. This is because during the depolarization phase of the action potential, sodium channels open, allowing sodium ions to enter the cell. However, during the repolarization phase of the action potential, potassium channels open, allowing potassium ions to exit the cell. Therefore, the membrane potential does not reach the equilibrium potential of sodium during the repolarization phase of the action potential.
What is the role of sodium channels in t: Sodium channels, specifically voltage-gated sodium channels, play a crucial role in the generation of action potentials in neurons. When the membrane potential reaches a certain threshold, sodium channels open, allowing sodium ions to rush into the cell, leading to depolarization. This rapid influx of sodium ions is essential for the all-or-nothing response of action potentials, which then triggers subsequent repolarization through the opening of potassium channels.
What is the role of the potassium channe: The role of potassium channels in the action potential is to regulate the repolarization phase of the membrane potential. During an action potential, voltage-gated potassium channels open, allowing potassium ions to flow out of the cell, which helps to restore the membrane potential back to its resting state. This process is essential for the proper propagation and repolarization of action potentials in neurons and other cells.
What are calcium-activated potassium cha: Calcium-activated potassium channels are ion channels that are activated by intracellular calcium. They are involved in various physiological processes such as neurotransmitter release, muscle contraction, and regulating membrane potential.
Why is an action potential normally unid: An action potential is normally unidirectional due to the refractory period of the axon membrane. Once a section of the axon membrane is depolarized, it cannot be depolarized again immediately. This prevents the action potential from traveling backwards.
In the CNS why are action potentials gen: In the CNS, action potentials are generally generated in the axon initial segment (AIS) because this region has a high concentration of voltage-gated sodium channels, which allow for the initiation of the depolarization needed for an action potential. This depolarization then propagates down the axon as a self-propagating wave of depolarization.
What is saltatory conduction ?: Saltatory conduction is the rapid propagation of action potentials along myelinated axons of neurons. In this process, the action potential "jumps" from one node of Ranvier to the next, increasing the conduction velocity. This process enhances the efficiency and speed of neural communication, which is essential for reflexes and complex motor functions. The myelin sheath, produced by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system (CNS) and Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system (PNS), insulates the ax
What is driving force equal to ?: The driving force is the external influence or stimulus that causes a system to undergo oscillations or vibrations. It is the primary factor that drives the motion or behavior of a system, particularly in the context of forced oscillations and resonance.
Why are calculated reversal potentials a: Calculated reversal potentials are always different to the real life reversal potentials because they are based on theoretical models that simplify the dynamics of ion channels and membrane potentials. In real-life systems, these models may not fully capture the complex interactions between ions and ion channels, leading to discrepancies between calculated and real-life reversal potentials.
What are phased neurones ?: Phased neurones refer to neurons that exhibit phase separation, a process where certain molecular components within the neuron separate into distinct phases, similar to how oil and water separate. This process can form membraneless biological condensates, which are concentrated areas of specific molecules that play crucial roles in neuronal functions, such as synaptic signaling and the regulation of neuronal stem cell development.
What are tonic neurones?: Tonic neurones are a type of neuron characterized by their continuous, low-frequency firing that occurs in both the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions of the autonomic nervous systems under a wide variety of conditions.
What are accommodating neurones ?: Accommodation neurones are neurons that adapt to a slowly rising current (ramp depolarization) in vitro, making it difficult to evoke an action potential. This phenomenon is known as neural accommodation.
What are spontaneous active bursting neu: Spontaneous active bursting neurones, also known as spontaneously bursting neurons, are neurons that exhibit bursts of activity without external stimulation. These bursts are characterized by rapid sequences of action potentials followed by periods of quiescence. This type of activity is important for various aspects of brain function, including the formation and refinement of neural circuits.
What is the patch-clamp technique ?: The patch-clamp technique is an electrophysiological technique used to study ionic currents in individual cells or patches of cell membrane. It allows researchers to measure the electrical activity of ion channels in living cells, and has revolutionized our understanding of cellular signaling and excitability.
What toxin can be used to block sodium c: The toxin that can be used to block sodium currents is tetrodotoxin (TTX).
What toxin can block potassium currents: One toxin that can block potassium currents is AETX-K, a peptide toxin from sea anemones.
What is the benefit of blocking the sodi: Blocking sodium and potassium channels independently can have different benefits depending on the specific condition being treated. Sodium channel blockers are commonly used to treat cardiac arrhythmias, while potassium channel blockers are commonly used to treat neurologic disorders such as Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease. It is important to note that blocking both sodium and potassium channels can have negative side effects and may not be suitable for all patients.
What are outwardly rectifying potassium: Outwardly rectifying potassium channels, also known as delayed rectifier potassium channels, are a type of potassium channel that allows the flow of potassium ions out of the cell more easily than it can flow in, particularly at positive membrane potentials. These channels play a crucial role in various physiological processes, including the regulation of membrane potential and cellular excitability.
What are inwardly rectifying potassium c: Inwardly rectifying potassium channels (IRK) are a type of potassium channel that allow potassium ions to flow more easily into the cell, particularly at membrane potentials negative to potassium's reversal potential. They play a crucial role in regulating cellular excitability and maintaining potassium homeostasis, with various subfamilies classified based on their activation mechanisms, such as classical Kir channels and G protein-gated Kir channels (GIRK).
What are depolarising activated non inac: Depolarising activated non-inactivating potassium channels (DANIKs) are a type of voltage-gated potassium channel that remains open and allows potassium ions to flow out of the cell when the membrane is depolarised, without undergoing inactivation. These channels play a crucial role in stabilizing the membrane potential and regulating neuronal excitability.
What are depolarising activated inactiva: Depolarising-activated inactivating potassium channels (DAIKs) are a type of potassium channel that opens in response to membrane depolarization and subsequently inactivates. They are involved in various physiological processes such as neurotransmitter release, action potential repolarization, and smooth muscle contraction.
What are depolarising and calcium activa: Depolarizing and calcium-activated potassium channels are two types of ion channels that are involved in various physiological processes. Depolarizing channels allow the influx of positive ions, leading to a decrease in the membrane potential, while calcium-activated potassium channels open in response to increased intracellular calcium levels, allowing potassium ions to flow out of the membrane and repolarize the cell.
What are cyclic nucleotide activated cat: Cyclic nucleotide activated cation channels are ion channels whose activation is regulated by the binding of cyclic nucleotides, such as cAMP or cGMP, to the channel protein. These channels play a role in various physiological processes, including neurotransmitter release and neuronal excitability.
What is an example of an inward rectifyi: An example of an inwardly rectifying potassium channel is the Kir2.2 channel.
What are the properties of the M channel: The M channel is a potassium channel that plays a crucial role in neuronal excitability and synchronization. It is primarily composed of KCNQ subunits and is regulated by neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine. Mutations in the M channel gene are associated with benign familial neonatal convulsions.
What is an example of an M channel activ: An example of an M channel activator is retigabine, which is a drug used in the treatment of epilepsy. The purpose of retigabine is to increase the activity of KCNQ channels, which are important in regulating neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission.
What is an example of an M channel inhib: An example of an M channel inhibitor is XE-991, which is a calcium channel blocker used in the treatment of high blood pressure.
What neurotransmitter inhibits M channel: The neurotransmitter that inhibits M channels is acetylcholine (ACh), specifically through muscarinic receptors. The consequence of this inhibition is a reduction in the M current, which affects neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission.
What are the effects of acetylcholine on: Acetylcholine binds to muscarinic receptors and activates various signaling pathways. Some of the effects of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors include vasodilation, smooth muscle contraction, and neurotransmitter release.
What happens when chloride channels are: When chloride channels are opened in mature neurones, it causes a hyperpolarization of the membrane potential. This is primarily due to the activation of GABAA receptors, which are permeable to chloride ions. This hyperpolarization of the membrane potential is important for maintaining synaptic plasticity and regulating neuronal excitability.
What happens to chloride when chloride c: When chloride channels are opened in an immature neurone, chloride ions flow out of the cell, resulting in a decrease in intracellular chloride concentration.
What happens when GABA binds to mature n: When GABA binds to mature neurones, it causes hyperpolarization of the postsynaptic neuron, generating an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP). This makes it less likely for an action potential to be generated, thereby inhibiting neuronal firing.
What happens when GABA binds to immature: When GABA binds to immature neurones, it causes depolarization and excitatory effects. This depolarization triggers sodium spikes and activates voltage-gated calcium channels, which can enhance synaptic plasticity and neuronal growth.
What are metabotropic receptors?: Metabotropic receptors are a type of membrane receptor that initiates metabolic processes to modulate cell activity, primarily through G-protein-coupled mechanisms. They are responsible for slower synaptic transmission and mediate the effects of various neurotransmitters.
If the membrane potential is at -90mV an: If the membrane potential is at -90mV and you get an inward current of sodium ions, the deflection of the excitatory postsynaptic current (EPSC) would be upward, indicating a depolarization of the postsynaptic membrane. Similarly, the deflection of the excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) would be downward, indicating a depolarization of the postsynaptic membrane.
If the membrane potential is at 0mV and: When the membrane potential is at 0mV and sodium channels open, the influx of sodium ions into the cell results in an excitatory postsynaptic current (EPSC) and an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP).
If the membrane potential is at +70mV an: When the membrane potential is at +70mV and the potassium channels are opened, potassium ions will flow out of the cell due to the electrochemical gradient. This will lead to a decrease in the excitatory postsynaptic current (EPSC) and excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP).
If the membrane potential was at - 70mV: If the membrane potential is at -70mV and chloride channels are opened, the excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) would decrease and the inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) would increase. This is because chloride ions, being negatively charged, would enter the cell, causing a decrease in the membrane potential and a decrease in the excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP).
What subunits are present in muscle nico: Muscle nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are composed of five subunits: two alpha () subunits and one each of beta (), gamma (), and delta () subunits.
What subunits are present in nicotinic a: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) in the brain are composed of various subunits, including alpha () and beta () subunits. The most common subtypes found in the brain are 42 and 7 subtypes.
How many alpha subunits have to be prese: The nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) requires at least two alpha subunits to form a functional receptor. This is because the binding of acetylcholine occurs at the interface between the alpha and beta subunits, which is essential for channel opening. Additionally, the stoichiometry of the alpha and beta subunits can influence the receptor's sensitivity to agonists and antagonists.
How many transmembrane domains are prese: A nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunit typically contains four transmembrane domains.
What are the 3 receptors for glutamate ?: The three ionotropic glutamate receptors are AMPA, NMDA, and kainate receptors.
What are NMDA receptors important for ?: NMDA receptors are important for synaptic plasticity and long-term potentiation (LTP). They are also involved in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Huntington's disease.
Which glutamate receptors are the most i: The most important glutamate receptors for excitation are the AMPA and NMDA receptors.
What are kainate receptors thought to be: Kainate receptors are thought to be involved in a variety of physiological processes, including neurotransmitter release, synaptic plasticity, and neuropathic pain.
Explain AMPA receptors ?: AMPA receptors are ionotropic glutamate receptors that mediate fast excitatory synaptic transmission in the central nervous system. They are found in both presynaptic and postsynaptic membranes and play a crucial role in normal brain function. AMPA receptors have a modular structure, with distinct regions for glutamate binding and ion channel formation, allowing for various receptor isoforms through the combination of different protein subunits.
When are more GluR1 only glutamate recep: GluR1-only glutamate receptors are mainly inserted into the membrane during long-term potentiation (LTP) processes in neurons.
Explain the structure of NMDA receptors: NMDA receptors are heterotetrameric ion channels composed of two obligatory GluN1 subunits and two alternative subunits, either GluN2 or GluN3. They are unique in that they exhibit a voltage-dependent calcium block that prevents channel opening at resting membrane potentials. The structure of NMDA receptors has been extensively studied, and recent studies have provided insights into their function and regulation.
When NMDA receptors become unblocked and: NMDA receptors become unblocked and allow the flow of ions when the membrane is depolarized enough to remove the magnesium ion (Mg2+) block that typically occludes the channel. This process is crucial for synaptic transmission and long-term potentiation (LTP).
What is an antagonist of AMPA/kainate re: An antagonist of AMPA/kainate receptors is a compound that blocks the activity of these receptors.
What is an antagonist of NMDA receptors: An antagonist of NMDA receptors is a substance that blocks the binding of glutamate to the receptor, preventing the influx of calcium ions into the neuron. Some examples of NMDA receptor antagonists include memantine, donepezil, and rasagiline.
What type of receptor is a GABAa recepto: A GABAa receptor is a type of ligand-gated ion channel that is activated by the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid).
When are GABA receptors inhibitory and w: GABA receptors can be both inhibitory and excitatory depending on the context. In mature neurons, GABA primarily acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter, regulating neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission. However, during early development, GABA can also act as an excitatory neurotransmitter, facilitating neuronal migration and other developmental processes.
What are the steps the follow activation: The activation of a metabotropic receptor typically involves the binding of a ligand to the receptor, followed by a conformational change in the receptor. This leads to the activation of G-protein-coupled receptors, which in turn activate downstream signaling pathways. Some examples of metabotropic receptors include the GluR1 and GluR2 receptors, which are both G-protein-coupled receptors.
What happens with noradrenaline binds to: When noradrenaline binds to a beta-adrenergic receptor, it activates the receptor and causes an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This leads to various physiological responses such as increased heart rate, smooth muscle relaxation, and increased blood pressure.
What happens when glutamate binds to mGl: When glutamate binds to the mGluR1 receptor, it activates a series of signaling cascades that can lead to changes in neuronal excitability and synaptic plasticity. This includes the activation of various kinases, phosphatases, and other signaling molecules.

When glutamate binds to mGluR2 receptors, it activates a G-protein-coupled signaling pathway that leads to a decrease in basal cAMP levels and an increase in phosphorylation of other mGluRs, such as mGluR5.
What happens when dopamine binds to dopa: When dopamine binds to the dopamine D2 receptor, it activates a signaling pathway that involves the activation of a protein complex involving Akt, beta-arrestin, and PP2A. This complex phosphorylates Akt, which in turn activates GSK-3, a protein that plays a role in neurotransmitter release and signaling in the brain.
Which glutamate receptors are more dense: The glutamate receptors that are more dense on the postsynaptic membrane are NMDA receptors, while the glutamate receptors that are more dense on the presynaptic membrane are AMPA receptors.
Why do metabotropic GABA receptors act a: Metabotropic GABA receptors act as dimers because they bind to and activate heterotrimeric G proteins, which mediate their signaling pathways. The dimeric structure of these receptors allows for asymmetric activation, which is crucial for their function.
What is a heteroreceptor ?: A heteroreceptor is a receptor that regulates the synthesis and/or release of mediators other than its own ligand.
What is an auto receptor ?: An auto receptor is a type of neurotransmitter receptor that is expressed in the presynaptic terminal of the same neuron that produces the neurotransmitter. Autoreceptors typically act as inhibitory receptors, limiting the amount of neurotransmitter released by the same neuron.
How does mGluR2 act as an autoreceptor ?: mGluR2 acts as an autoreceptor by inhibiting the release of glutamate from presynaptic terminals of glutamatergic neurons. This inhibition is mediated through a G protein-coupled mechanism that reduces the emptying of vesicles, thereby reducing synaptic transmission.
How is acetylcholine made ?: Acetylcholine is synthesized from choline and acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl CoA) by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT). The reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT).
Why is ChAT enzyme so important ?: ChAT enzyme, or choline acetyltransferase, is important because it catalyzes the synthesis of acetylcholine (ACh), a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in signaling in the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system. ACh deficiency can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease.
How is the production of acetylcholine i: The production of acetylcholine can be inhibited by blocking the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE), which breaks down acetylcholine into choline and acetate. This can be achieved through the use of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, which block the enzyme's activity and increase acetylcholine levels.
What transporter is used to store acetyl: The transporter used to store acetylcholine is the vesicular acetylcholine transporter (VAChT).
How is acetylcholine inactivated in the: Acetylcholine is inactivated in the synaptic cleft by the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which is located on the postsynaptic membrane. This enzyme rapidly splits acetylcholine into choline and acetate, neither of which can activate the acetylcholine receptors.
How does hemicolinium work ?: Hemicolinium works by blocking the reuptake of choline by the high-affinity choline transporter (ChT) at the presynaptic terminal. This decreases the synthesis of acetylcholine, leading to a neuromuscular block.
How does vesamicol work ?: Vesamicol works by inhibiting the transport of acetylcholine (ACh) into synaptic vesicles in cholinergic nerve terminals. This action is presynaptic and results in a non-competitive and reversible block of the intracellular transporter VAChT, which is responsible for carrying newly synthesized ACh into secretory vesicles. By inhibiting this transport, vesamicol reduces the release of ACh at cholinergic synapses.
How does botulinium work ?: Botulinum toxin works by blocking the release of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that signals muscles to contract. This causes temporary muscle paralysis, which is used for various medical and cosmetic purposes.
How does nicotine work ?: Nicotine works by binding to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) in the brain and stimulating the release of dopamine and other neurotransmitters. This stimulation can lead to feelings of pleasure and euphoria, and can also contribute to nicotine addiction.
How does scopolamine work ?: Scopolamine, also known as hyoscine or Devil's Breath, works by blocking certain nerve signals in the brain that cause nausea and vomiting. It also reduces stomach fluid production and slows down gut movements, which helps to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by motion sickness or anesthesia.
Where are the major clusters of choliner: The major clusters of cholinergic pathways in the CNS are located in the basal nucleus of Meynert and the septal-hippocampal regions.
How many muscarinic acetylcholine recept: There are five subtypes of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (M1 to M5) and they are typically coupled to G proteins, specifically Gq/11, Gi/o, and Gs.
Where is muscarinic ACh M1 expressed in: Muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (mAChR) subtype M1 is predominantly expressed in the brain, particularly in the striatum and prefrontal cortex.
Where are muscarinic ACh M2 receptors ex: Muscarinic ACh M2 receptors are expressed in various regions of the brain, including the striatum, hippocampus, and cerebral cortex.
Where are muscarinic ACh M3 receptors ex: Muscarinic ACh M3 receptors are widely expressed in the brain, including the hypothalamus, hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis, and hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis.
Where are muscarinic ACh M4 receptors ex: Muscarinic ACh M4 receptors are expressed in various regions of the brain, including the hippocampus, where they are found in a subset of hippocampal neural progenitor cells (NPCs).
Where are muscarinic ACh M5 receptors ex: Muscarinic ACh M5 receptors are expressed in the brain in various regions, including the striatum, hypothalamus, and hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis.
What is the sea shell shaped structure i: The sea shell shaped structure in the brain is called the hippocampus. It is located in the medial temporal lobe and plays a crucial role in memory formation and retrieval.
What paired structure lies immediately m: The globus pallidus lies immediately medial to the putamen.
Which structure is more rostral - optic: The optic chiasm is more rostral than the mammillary bodies.
What cerebellar peduncles connect the po: The superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the pons to the cerebellum.
What cerebellar peduncles connect the mi: The superior cerebellar peduncles connect the midbrain to the cerebellum.
What cerebellar peduncles connect the me: The superior and inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the medulla to the cerebellum.
What fluid is produced in the ventricula: The fluid produced in the ventricular system is cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Which structures of the ventricular syst: The interventricular foramen, also known as the foramen of Monro, connects the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle within the ventricular system.
What is the interthalamic adhesion and w: The interthalamic adhesion, also known as the intermediate mass or middle commissure, is a flattened band of tissue that connects the medial surfaces of both thalami in the brain. It is located at the midline, forming a bridge between the two thalamic hemispheres.
What is the clinical term for a rise in: The clinical term for a rise in intracranial pressure due to obstruction of CSF is obstructive hydrocephalus.
What 2 structures does the cerebral aque: The cerebral aqueduct lies underneath the tectum and the corpus callosum.
Where does the cerebral aqueduct open in: The cerebral aqueduct, also known as the aqueduct of Sylvius, opens into the third ventricle at its posterior end.
What structures form the lateral walls o: The lateral walls of the third ventricle are formed by the medial surfaces of the thalamus.
What secretes CSF?: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is secreted by the choroid plexus, which is located in the walls of the lateral ventricles and the roofs of the third and fourth ventricles.
What is another name for interventricula: The interventricular foramen is also known as the foramen of Monro.
At what level of the brain does the cent: The central canal opens into the 4th ventricle at the level of the obex, which is located in the medulla oblongata.
What is the function of cerebral aqueduc: The function of the cerebral aqueduct is to allow the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) between the third and fourth ventricles of the brain.
Where are sensory neuron ganglions in th: Sensory neuron ganglions in the spinal cord are located in the dorsal root ganglia, which are located on the dorsal roots of the spinal nerves.
Where are interneurons in the spinal cor: Interneurons in the spinal cord are primarily located in the gray matter, specifically in the dorsal and ventral horns.
In the spinal cord where are you most li: Large neuronal cell bodies in the spinal cord are typically found in the dorsal root ganglia. These ganglia are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the periphery to the spinal cord.
What neurons are present in the lateral: The lateral column of the spinal cord contains neurons that control the sympathetic nervous system. These neurons primarily use acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter and send their axons to synapse on sympathetic ganglia that innervate autonomic and pelvic organs.
Which level of the spinal cord is the la: The lateral horn of the spinal cord is seen most clearly in the thoracic and upper lumbar spinal segments (T1 to L2).
Which tracts arise in the red nucleus an: Tracts that arise in the red nucleus and tectum include the dentatorubral tract and the tectospinal tract. The tectospinal tract lies most dorsally.
What is the fasiculus cuneatus and fasic: The fasciculus cuneatus and fasciculus gracilis are two sensory pathways in the spinal cord. The fasciculus cuneatus carries sensory information from the upper extremities and terminates at the nucleus cuneatus in the caudal medulla, while the fasciculus gracilis carries sensory information from the lower extremities and terminates at the nucleus gracile in the caudal medulla.
Which lies more laterally, fasiculus cun: The fasciculus cuneatus lies more laterally than the fasciculus gracilis.
What structures make up the basal gangli: The basal ganglia consists of five pairs of nuclei: the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus, and substantia nigra.
Which electrodes in an EEG are positione: The electrodes in an EEG that are positioned closest to the visual cortex are called the occipital electrodes, specifically O1 and O2.
When would you expect to see beta waves: Beta waves are typically associated with active, alert states of consciousness, such as when engaged in problem-solving, decision-making, or focused attention.
Which waves out of alpha and delta waves: Alpha waves have the largest amplitude, while delta waves have the smallest amplitude.
Why do delta waves have a larger amplitu: Delta waves have a larger amplitude due to the synchronized activity of neurons in the brain during deep sleep. This synchronization increases the amplitude of delta waves.
What types of clinical uses does the EEG: The EEG (electroencephalogram) is used in clinical settings to diagnose and monitor a variety of neurological conditions, including epilepsy, sleep disorders, and brain injuries. It can also be used to monitor changes in brain activity during certain medical procedures, such as brain surgery or neurosurgery.
What are the cranial nerves in order ?: The cranial nerves in order are: 1. Olfactory (I) 2. Optic (II) 3. Oculomotor (III) 4. Trochlear (IV) 5. Trigeminal (V) 6. Abducens (VI) 7. Facial (VII)
Which cranial nerves enter/exit the pons: The cranial nerves that enter/exit the pons (pons/medulla boundary) are the trigeminal nerve (CN V), abducens nerve (CN VI), facial nerve (CN VII), and vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).
Which cranial nerves enter/exit the midb: The cranial nerves that enter/exit the midbrain are the oculomotor nerve (III) and the trochlear nerve (IV).
Which cranial nerve exits on the dorsal: The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is the only cranial nerve that exits on the dorsal surface of the brain.
Which cranial nerves have both afferent: The cranial nerves that have both afferent and efferent branches are the trigeminal nerve (CN V), the facial nerve (CN VII), the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), and the vagus nerve (CN X).
Which nerve would be used to carry info: The nerve that would be used to carry info relating to very sweet food is the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which innervates the posterior third of the tongue.
Which cranial nerve is used to carry inf: The cranial nerve responsible for carrying information about bitter food is the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
Which cranial nerve is used to control c: The trigeminal nerve, also known as cranial nerve 5, is responsible for controlling chewing and swallowing.
What is the function of the pons ?: The pons is a part of the brain that serves as a communication bridge between the forebrain and the cerebellum. It is responsible for transmitting sensory and motor signals from the forebrain to the cerebellum. The pons also plays a role in motor control, particularly in the head and neck.
What is the function of the medulla ?: The medulla oblongata, or simply the medulla, is a part of the brainstem that is responsible for various autonomic functions such as breathing, heart rate, and digestion. It also plays a role in reflex actions such as vomiting and sneezing.
What does hemiplegia mean ?: Hemiplegia is a condition characterized by severe or complete paralysis on one side of the body. It is usually caused by brain damage in the cerebral hemisphere opposite to the affected side.
What are the clinical consequences of le: A lesion in the left optic tract typically results in right-sided homonymous hemianopsia, which means loss of vision in the right half of the visual field in both eyes.
What are the common causes of hemiballis: The common causes of hemiballismus include damage to the subthalamic nucleus in the brain, vascular lesions in the brain, and hypothyroidism.
What are common causes of upper motor ne: The most common cause of upper motor neuron disease is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. It is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects both upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness, spasticity, and eventual paralysis.
What are the causes of Trigeminal neural: Trigeminal neuralgia can be caused by a variety of factors, including vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve, facial trauma or surgery, and certain medical conditions such as multiple sclerosis.
