It can also be caused by a variety of other factors, including genetics, infections, and certain medications.
What is the function of the optic chiasm: The optic chiasma is a structure located at the base of the brain where the optic nerves from the left and right eyes converge and cross. Its primary function is to facilitate binocular vision by allowing visual information from the nasal (inner) halves of the retinas to cross to the opposite side of the brain, which is essential for depth perception and hand-eye coordination.
What is the function of the olfactory bu: The olfactory bulb is the main relay station in the olfactory pathway. It processes sensory information from olfactory receptors in the nose and transmits it to the olfactory cortex for further processing.
What is the function of the mammillary b: The mammillary bodies are part of the extended hippocampal system and play a crucial role in mnemonic processes, spatial and working memory, and navigation. They receive inputs from the hippocampus via the fornix and play a significant role in processing spatial and working memory, and damage to these structures is associated with anterograde amnesia.
What is the function of the superior col: The superior colliculus is a midbrain structure that plays a central role in visual processing, orienting attention, and coordinating eye and head movements. It integrates visual and non-visual information and is involved in transforming sensory information into motor actions.
What is the function of the periaqueduct: The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical brain region involved in autonomic function, pain modulation, and behavioral responses to threats. It serves as the primary control center for descending pain modulation, activating enkephalin-releasing neurons that project to the brainstem, which can lead to profound analgesia. Additionally, the PAG plays a role in integrating emotional and defensive behaviors, influencing responses to pain and stress.
What is the function of the inferior oli: The function of the inferior olive is to provide climbing fiber input to Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, generating large bursts of Purkinje cell activity known as complex spikes.
What is the function of the raphe nucleu: The dorsal raphe nucleus is a cluster of neurons in the brainstem that produce and release serotonin. It plays a crucial role in regulating sleep-wake cycles, as well as mood and anxiety.
What is the function of the red nucleus: The red nucleus is a part of the cerebellum that is involved in motor control. It serves as a relay station for information from the motor cortex to the cerebellum.
What is the function of the substantia g: The substantia gelatinosa is a grey matter structure in the dorsal spinal cord primarily involved in the transmission and modulation of pain, temperature, and touch sensations. It is a key player in sensory processing and pain modulation within the spinal cord.
What is the function of the spinothalami: The spinothalamic tract is a pathway in the central nervous system that transmits pain, temperature, and touch sensations to the thalamus. It originates in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord and sends axons to the thalamus, where it is further processed.
What is the function of the corticospina: The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is the primary pathway for voluntary motor control, connecting the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. It transmits motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord, where they influence motor neurons. Damage to this tract can result in motor deficits, particularly affecting the contralateral side of the body.
What is the function of the lissauers tr: Lissauer's tract is a white matter tract in the spinal cord that transmits somatosensory information from the skin to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. It is involved in the spinothalamic pathway, which transmits sensory information from the skin to the thalamus.
What are the clinical consequences of a: The clinical consequences of a thoracic spinal cord hemilesion can vary depending on the severity of the injury. It can result in motor and sensory deficits on the opposite side of the lesion, as well as loss of sensation on the same side of the lesion. It is important to seek medical attention immediately after the injury to ensure proper diagnosis and treatment.

Clinical consequences of a unilateral brainstem lesion can vary depending on the location and severity of the lesion. Some common symptoms include weakness or paresis on the same side as the lesion, disruption of the ascending reticular activating system, and respiratory dysfunction, particularly if the lesion is located more caudally.
What are the clinical consequences of un: Unilateral cerebellar hemispheric lesion can lead to a variety of clinical consequences, including ataxia, dysarthria, and intention tremor. These symptoms can vary depending on the location and severity of the lesion.
What are the clinical consequences of ce: Clinical consequences of cerebral hemispheric lesion can vary depending on the location and severity of the lesion. Left hemisphere lesions may result in language and cognitive deficits, while right hemisphere lesions may result in motor and sensory deficits. Additionally, cerebral hemispheric lesions can also lead to a variety of neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and epilepsy.
What causes hemiballismus ?: Hemiballismus is caused by decreased activity in the subthalamic nucleus of the basal ganglia. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including stroke, brain injury, autoimmune disorders, and certain medications.
What are the causes of subdural haemotom: Subdural hematomas are caused by head injuries, such as falls, car accidents, or assaults. These injuries cause bleeding into the space between the skull and the brain, which is called the subdural space. The exact cause of a subdural hematoma is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by ruptured blood vessels in the dura mater, which is the outermost layer of the brain.
What are the causes of hydrocephalus ?: Hydrocephalus is caused by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain. The main causes of hydrocephalus are blockages in the flow of CSF, such as tumors, cysts, or birth defects. Poor absorption of CSF can also cause hydrocephalus, particularly in preterm infants.
What are the causes of multiple sclerosi: The exact cause of multiple sclerosis is not known, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental, and viral factors. It is believed that the immune system mistakenly attacks the protective myelin sheath around nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord.
What are the causes of upper motor neuro: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It is caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, including a shortened telomere length, a shortened p53 gene, and exposure to organochlorine pesticides.
What are the causes of trigeminal neural: Trigeminal neuralgia is primarily caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including facial trauma, tumors, arteriovenous malformations, and autoimmune disorders. Other possible causes include autoimmune disorders, infections, and certain medications.
What are the causes of Bell\u2019s palsy: The exact cause of Bell's palsy is not known, but it is believed to be caused by a viral or bacterial infection of the facial nerve. It is more common in pregnant women and people with certain medical conditions, such as autoimmune disorders or inflammatory bowel disease. In some cases, the cause is idiopathic, meaning there is no known cause.
What makes up the lentiform nucleus ?: The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus.
What makes up the basal ganglia ?: The basal ganglia are composed of several structures, including the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.
What happens to the dorsal column pathwa: At the medulla, the dorsal column pathways synapse with neurons in the nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus. These neurons transmit sensory information from the dorsal column to the thalamus and spinal cord.
What does the cingulate gurus form into: The cingulate gyrus is a part of the brain's limbic system and plays a role in controlling emotions and regulating behavior. It is divided into four parts: the anterior cingulate gyrus, the midcingulate gyrus, the posterior cingulate gyrus, and the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus.
What is the uncus ?: The uncus is a small projection on the medial surface of the parahippocampal gyrus in the brain, located at the medial end of the temporal lobe. It plays a significant role in olfactory processing and is associated with temporal lobe seizures, which may be preceded by olfactory or gustatory hallucinations.
Which part of the medulla has the centra: The central canal runs through the dorsal part of the medulla oblongata.
What makes up the floor of the 4th ventr: The floor of the 4th ventricle is formed by the dorsal surfaces of the pons and the rostral medulla. It is divided into symmetrical halves by the midline median sulcus.
What makes up the roof of the 4th ventri: The roof of the fourth ventricle is made up of a membrane called the tela choroidea, which is composed of ependymal cells and a double layer of pia mater.
What are 2 prominent aspects on the dors: Two prominent aspects on the dorsal surface of the midbrain are the superior colliculus and the inferior colliculus.
What are the cerebral peduncles?: The cerebral peduncles are two stalk-like structures in the midbrain that connect the cerebrum to the brainstem. They contain large ascending (sensory) and descending (motor) tracts that run to and from the cerebrum from the pons. The cerebral peduncles play a crucial role in refining motor movements and maintaining balance and posture.
What is the interpeduncular fossa?: The interpeduncular fossa is a depression located at the base of the brain, situated between the cerebral peduncles. It is bounded anteriorly by the optic chiasm and posteriorly by the pons.
Where does the hypoglossal nerve arise f: The hypoglossal nerve arises from the hypoglossal nucleus in the medulla oblongata of the brain.
What nerves arise from the Cerebellar po: The seventh cranial nerve (facial nerve) and the eighth cranial nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve) arise from the cerebellopontine angle.
What nerve arises from the medullary/pon: The abducens nerve (CN VI) arises from the medullary/pontine junction.
What is the vermis ?: The vermis is a narrow, worm-like structure located between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum in the brain. It plays a crucial role in coordinating movement and maintaining posture by integrating sensory information from the body to ensure smooth, coordinated muscle movements.
What is the function of the parietal lob: The parietal lobe is responsible for receiving and interpreting somatosensory signals, such as touch and position sensations, and integrating sensory information from different parts of the body. It also plays a role in proprioception, which is the ability to sense one's body's position in space.
What is the function of the frontal lobe: The frontal lobe is responsible for high-level cognitive functions such as attention, problem-solving, decision-making, and impulse control. It also plays a role in motor control and speech production.
What is the function of the temporal lob: The temporal lobe is primarily responsible for processing auditory stimuli, memory, and emotion. It contains the primary auditory complex, which is responsible for interpreting sounds and assigning meaning to them. Additionally, the temporal lobe plays a role in storing and retrieving memories, regulating emotions, and understanding language.
What is the function of the occipital lo: The occipital lobe is responsible for processing visual stimuli and interpreting information from the eyes. It plays a crucial role in spatial perception, object recognition, and visual memory.
What is the function of the thalamus ?: The thalamus is a small structure in the brain that plays a crucial role in processing and relaying sensory and motor information to the cerebral cortex. It is often described as the brain's relay station because much of the information that reaches the cerebral cortex first stops in the thalamus before it is sent to its destination.
What is the largest part of the basal ga: The largest part of the basal ganglia is the corpus striatum, which includes the caudate nucleus and the putamen.
What is the function of the basal gangli: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei located deep within the brain that play a crucial role in controlling voluntary movements. They are involved in various functions, including motor control, sensory perception, and procedural learning. Basal ganglia also provide feedback to the cerebral cortex, helping to refine and regulate motor activity.
What is the falx cerebri ?: The falx cerebri is a large, crescent-shaped fold of dura mater that descends into the longitudinal fissure to separate the cerebral hemispheres. It supports the dural sinuses, which are responsible for venous and CSF drainage from the brain.
What is the internal capsule ?: The internal capsule is a paired white matter structure in the brain that contains ascending and descending axons, which carry information to and from the cerebral cortex. It is a crucial component of the brain's neural network, facilitating communication and information transfer between different regions of the brain.
What fibres are present in the corpus ca: The corpus callosum is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres. It contains approximately 200 million heavily myelinated fibers, which are primarily axons.
What is the tentorium cerebelli ?: The tentorium cerebelli is a fold of the dura mater that separates the occipital lobe of the brain from the underlying cerebellum and brainstem. It is part of the posterior cranial fossa meninges and receives its arterial supply from the ascending pharyngeal, occipital, and vertebral arteries.
How does info enter the limbic system ?: Information enters the limbic system through various sensory inputs such as visual, auditory, and olfactory stimuli. These sensory inputs are processed by the thalamus and relayed to various limbic structures such as the hippocampus, amygdala, and hypothalamus. The limbic system plays a crucial role in regulating emotions, motivation, and behavior.
What is the septum pellucidum ?: The septum pellucidum is a thin, triangular-shaped, membranous structure that separates the two cerebral hemispheres, separating the anterior horns and bodies of the lateral ventricles. In a typical developing brain, this membrane fuses shortly after birth, creating a solid partition. However, in some cases, this fusion fails to occur, resulting in a persistent cavity known as the cavum septum.
What are the folds of the cerebellar cor: The folds of the cerebellar cortex are called folia.
Why does the development of the cerebral: The development of the cerebral hemispheres forms a C shape due to a process called gyrification. Gyrification is the process by which the cortical walls of the cerebral cortex grow much faster than the floor of the cerebral cortex. As the hemispheres grow, the caudal ends of the lateral ventricles turn ventrally and then rostrally, forming the temporal lobes and temporal ventricular horns. This process results in the characteristic C-shaped shape of the cerebral hemispheres.
What is the corona radiata ?: The corona radiata is a white matter structure in the brain that consists of projection fibers that radiate from the cerebral cortex to the brainstem, continuing as the internal capsule. It plays a crucial role in connecting various parts of the brain and is involved in motor function, with evidence suggesting a somatotopic arrangement of motor fibers.
Subcortical structures include the thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and limbic system. These structures are located beneath the cerebral cortex and play important roles in various functions such as movement, emotion, and sensory processing.
Where is language almost always processe: Language is almost always processed in the left hemisphere of the brain, particularly in areas such as Broca's area and Wernicke's area. These areas are involved in speech production and comprehension.
Where is Broca\u2019s area ?: Broca's area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, typically the left one. It is involved in language production and comprehension.
What is Broca\u2019s aphasias ?: Broca's aphasia is a type of non-fluent aphasia characterized by difficulty in speech production. It is caused by damage to the Broca's area in the brain, which is responsible for language production. People with Broca's aphasia often speak in short, fragmented sentences and may omit small linking words, leading to telegraphic speech.
Where is wernickes area ?: Wernicke's area is located in the posterior segment of the superior temporal gyrus in the left hemisphere of the brain.
What is wernickes aphasias ?: Wernicke's aphasia is a language disorder caused by damage to the Wernicke's area in the brain. It is characterized by impaired comprehension of spoken and written language, while the ability to produce fluent speech remains relatively intact.
What does split brain mean and what are: Split brain refers to a neurological condition where the connection between the left and right hemispheres of the brain is severed or significantly impaired. This can lead to a range of effects, including difficulty in communication between the hemispheres, a split personality-like experience, and a range of bizarre behaviors and symptoms.
What are the 2 enlargements of the spina: The two enlargements of the spinal cord are the cervical enlargement (from C4 to T1) and the lumbar enlargement (from T9 to T12).
What effect does the different lengths o: The different lengths of the vertebral canal and spinal cord can cause a variety of effects depending on the severity of the condition. For example, spinal stenosis can cause pressure on the spinal cord and nerves, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, and weakness.
What is the denticulate ligament ?: Denticulate ligaments are lateral projections of the spinal pia mater that anchor the spinal cord to the dura mater along its length.
Why do higher levels of the spinal cord: Higher levels of the spinal cord contain more white matter because they are responsible for transmitting sensory and motor information to the brain. As you move up the spinal cord, there is an increase in the number of sensory and motor neurons, which require more myelinated axons for communication. Additionally, as you move up the spinal cord, there is an increase in the number of motor neurons, which require more myelinated axons for communication.
Which levels of the spinal cord contain: The lateral horn of the spinal cord is present in the thoracic, upper lumbar, and sacral regions. It contains preganglionic sympathetic neurons, which are part of the autonomic nervous system.
What is hypoxaemia ?: Hypoxemia is a condition characterized by low levels of oxygen in the blood.
What is ventilation ?: Ventilation refers to the movement of fresh air into and out of a closed space, or the system that does this. In biological terms, it refers to the act of breathing, specifically pulmonary ventilation, where air is exchanged between the lungs and the environment. This process is essential for maintaining air quality and supporting life by providing oxygen and removing carbon dioxide.
What are the 4 basic causes of hypoxaemi: The four basic causes of hypoxemia are hypoventilation, ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion impairment, and high altitude.
What determines the partial pressure of: The partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli is determined by the alveolar gas equation, which takes into account factors such as atmospheric pressure, the fraction of oxygen inspired, and the difference between atmospheric pressure and water vapor pressure.
What is hypoventilation ?: Hypoventilation, also known as respiratory depression, occurs when ventilation is insufficient to meet the body's needs for gas exchange, leading to an increased concentration of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) and respiratory acidosis. It is characterized by slow or shallow breathing, which can lead to a lack of oxygen and a buildup of acid in the body.
What are the causes of hypoventilation ?: Hypoventilation can be caused by a variety of factors, including neuromuscular disorders, central nervous system disorders, alcohol or drug overdose, and certain medical conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or sleep apnea. It is important to seek medical attention if you or someone you know is experiencing hypoventilation.
When does the diffusion limit become lar: The diffusion limit becomes larger when the distance between particles in a system increases. For example, in a molecular liquid, the diffusion limit becomes larger as the ratio of the second-order correlation time to shear viscosity decreases.
What is shunted blood ?: Shunted blood refers to blood that bypasses the lungs without undergoing gas exchange. This can occur due to anatomical shunts, such as atrial septal defects, or physiological shunts, such as intrapulmonary shunting due to lung diseases.
What are some of the causes of shunted b: Shunted blood can be caused by a variety of factors, including anatomical shunts, congenital heart defects, and lung diseases such as pulmonary hypertension or emphysema.
What happens to the resistance in the pu: When pulmonary arterial pressure rises, the resistance in the pulmonary circulation (PVR) increases. This is because the diameter of the pulmonary arteries decreases when pulmonary arterial pressure rises, leading to an increase in the resistance to blood flow. This increase in resistance can be caused by various factors, such as increased blood flow to the lungs, decreased blood flow to the heart, and vascular remodeling.
What is the relationship between the dis: The relationship between the distribution of blood flow though an upright human lung is known as the ventilation-perfusion ratio. In the upright position, the apex of the upper lobe of the right lung has the highest ventilation-perfusion ratio, while the apex of the lower lobe of the left lung has the lowest ventilation-perfusion ratio.
What happens to blood flow throughout th: During exercise, blood flow throughout the lungs increases. Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases, allowing more blood to flow through the lungs. Capillary density and diffusion capacity also increase, enhancing oxygen uptake. Additionally, there is a redistribution of blood flow, prioritizing respiratory muscles over other skeletal muscles.
What are the 3 main forces that affect b: The three main forces that affect blood flow through the lungs are the pressure gradient, vascular resistance, and compliance of the pulmonary vessels.
Explain zone 1 of the flow zones in an u: Zone 1 of the flow zones in an upright lung is located at the apex, where the alveolar pressure (Palv) exceeds the pulmonary artery and vein pressures. This results in limited pulmonary blood flow and is commonly referred to as 'dead space'.
Explain zone 2 of the flow zones in an u: Zone 2 of the flow zones in an upright lung is the intermediate zone. In this zone, arterial pressure is higher than alveolar pressure, while venous pressure remains lower than alveolar pressure. This zone is responsible for maintaining the balance between arterial and venous pressures, allowing for efficient pulmonary blood flow.
Explain zone 3 of the flow zones in an u: Zone 3 of the flow zones in an upright lung is located at the base of the lung, where both arterial and venous pressures exceed alveolar pressure. What happens if you damage peripheral or: Damage to peripheral or central components of the somatosensory system can result in a variety of sensory impairments, including loss of sensation, numbness, tingling, and pain sensations. What is the fundamental function of the: The somatosensory system is responsible for the perception of sensations such as touch, pressure, pain, temperature, and vibration. It also plays a role in regulating body position and balance (proprioception).
What are primary afferents ?: Primary afferents are sensory neurons in the peripheral nervous system that transmit information about mechanical, thermal, and chemical states of the body to the central nervous system.
What are motor efferents ?: Motor efferents are nerves that transmit motor signals from the central nervous system (CNS) to the muscles. Autonomic motor efferents arise within the ventral ventricular zone, an anteriorly situated region near the central canal of the spinal cord. What are dermatomes ?: Dermatomes are areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerve fibers from a specific spinal nerve ganglion. Dermatomes are important in clinical assessments for conditions like radiculopathy, where nerve root compression can lead to specific sensory symptoms in the corresponding dermatome.
Dermatome boundaries are overlapping. Wh: Advantages of overlapping dermatome boundaries include redundancy in sensory innervation, which means that if one nerve is damaged, there is often minimal loss of sensation due to the contributions from adjacent nerves. What are the 4 classes of somatosensory: The four classes of somatosensory receptors are mechanoreceptors, nociceptors, thermoreceptors, and proprioceptors.
What a Meissners corpuscles ?: Meissner corpuscles, also known as Wagner-Meissner corpuscles or tactile corpuscles, are specialized nerve endings in the skin that are responsible for sensitivity to light touch and low-frequency vibrations. They are located in the dermal papillae of glabrous skin and are particularly sensitive to vibrations between 10 and 50 hertz.
What are merkels disks ?: Merkel's discs, also known as Merkel cell-neurite complexes, are specialized mechanoreceptors located in the skin that are responsible for sensing light touch and texture. They consist of Merkel cells that are connected to sensory nerve endings and play a crucial role in tactile perception, particularly in areas of the skin that are sensitive to fine detail, such as the fingertips and lips.
What are pacinian corpuscles ?: Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors found in the skin and other tissues, primarily responsible for detecting high-frequency vibrations and pressure changes. They are characterized by their onion-like structure, consisting of multiple layers of connective tissue that encapsulate a nerve ending, allowing them to respond rapidly to mechanical deformation. These receptors are particularly sensitive to vibrations around 250 Hz and play a crucial role in the sensation of touch and proprioception.
What are ruffinis endings !?: Ruffini's endings, also known as Ruffini corpuscles, are mechanoreceptors located in the skin and joints. They respond primarily to skin stretching and are involved in sensing static position, changes in intra-articular pressure, and the direction and velocity of movement. These receptors play a crucial role in proprioception, helping to generate awareness of finger and hand position.
What are the rapidly activity cutaneous: Rapidly adapting cutaneous mechanoreceptors (RACMs) are specialized sensory receptors that detect rapid changes in mechanical stimuli, such as changes in temperature, pressure, and vibration. The most common types of RACMs are Meissner corpuscles, which detect light touch, and Pacinian corpuscles, which detect deep pressure.
What are the slowly activity cutaneous m: Slowly adapting cutaneous mechanoreceptors (SACMs) are a type of somatosensory neuron that responds to mechanical stimuli with a sustained firing pattern. They are primarily found in the superficial layer of the skin and play a crucial role in the perception of touch, pressure, and texture.
Which mechanoreceptors are characteristi: Mechanoreceptors with discrete receptive fields of the hand include Merkel cells, Meissner corpuscles, and Pacinian corpuscles. Mechanoreceptors with more broad receptive zones include Ruffini endings, Meissner cells, and Meissner corpuscles.
What is human 2 point discrimination thr: Human two-point discrimination thresholds (2PDT) refer to the minimum distance at which a person can perceive two distinct points of touch on the skin. This threshold varies across different body areas, being finer in regions with a higher density of sensory receptors, such as the fingertips. The 2PDT is commonly used to assess tactile spatial acuity and the functionality of the somatosensory system.
What are the theories of mechanotransduc: Mechanotransduction is the process by which cells convert mechanical stimuli into biochemical signals that elicit cellular responses, such as gene activation or cell migration. What are the example channels involved i: Some example channels involved in mechanotransduction include Piezo1 and Piezo2, which are mechanosensitive ion channels that respond to mechanical stimuli.
What happens when capsaicin binds to VR1: When capsaicin binds to VR1, it activates the vanilloid receptor 1 (VR1), leading to the opening of the channel. What receptor family is involved in ther: The transient receptor potential (TRP) family of cation channels is involved in thermoregulation.

What fibres are associated with nocicept: Nociceptors are associated with two types of fibers: C-fibers (unmyelinated) and A-fibers (myelinated). What does muscle spindle and Golgi tendo: Muscle spindle detects changes in muscle length, while Golgi tendon organ detects changes in muscle tension.
What are the properties of group 1(a-alp: Group 1(a-alpha) afferents, also known as primary afferents, are characterized by their large diameter and myelination, which allows for rapid conduction of action potentials. What are the properties of group 2(a-bet: Group 2(a-beta) afferents are characterized by their conduction velocities, which can vary greatly depending on the specific type of afferent. What are the properties of a-delta affer: A-delta afferents are myelinated fibers that transmit sharp, acute pain signals with high intensity and short latency, facilitating quick withdrawal responses. What are the properties of c afferents ?: C afferents are low-threshold mechanoreceptors that convey positive and pleasant aspects of touch, responding optimally to gentle, caress-like contact. They have unmyelinated, slowly conducting axons, which results in a delayed signal to the brain and high sensitivity to small displacements of the skin, especially from dynamic, moving touch.
Which laminae do each of the afferent fi: Each of the afferent fibers terminate in specific laminae in the spinal cord. C fibers terminate in laminae I and II, while A fibers terminate in laminae I, II, V, and VI.
What info is carried in the dorsal colun: The dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway carries information related to fine touch (tactile sensation), vibration, and proprioception from the body to the cerebral cortex.

What is asteroagnosia ?: Astereognosis is the inability to recognize objects by touch alone, without visual input. It is a type of sensory disorder that affects the ability to identify objects through tactile manipulation.

What receptors detect chemicals ?: There are several receptors that detect chemicals, including olfactory receptors for smell, taste receptors for taste, and chemoreceptors for smell.

What receptors detect cold ?: Thermoreceptors, also known as cold receptors, are small-diameter, unmyelinated sensory neurons that express the cold-sensitive ion channel TRPM8 (Transient Receptor Potential Melastatin 8). What happens in the zone of lissauer and: The zone of Lissauer, also known as Lissauer's tract, is a region in the spinal cord where sensory axons enter and branch extensively before synapsing in the posterior horn. This zone facilitates spinal reflexes and transmits sensory information through the spinothalamic tracts.
What is the substantia gelatinosa ?: The substantia gelatinosa is a grey gelatinous mass located at the apex of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. It plays a crucial role in sensory processing and pain modulation, receiving inputs from various sensory fibers and containing densely packed small neurons.
What is referred pain ?: Referred pain is the sensation of pain perceived in a location different from the site of the painful stimulus. This phenomenon occurs because of the interconnected nature of sensory nerves, which can cause the brain to misinterpret the source of the pain signals. Common examples include shoulder pain resulting from a heart attack or back pain resulting from a neck injury.
Examples of referred pain?: Referred pain refers to pain that is felt in areas that are not the source of the pain itself. Some examples of referred pain include pain in the neck, shoulder, or back that is caused by a musculoskeletal injury, pain in the arm or leg that is caused by a nerve injury, and pain in the face or jaw that is caused by a toothache.
What are the 3 ascending pain pathways ?: The three ascending pain pathways are the neospinothalamic tract, the paleospinothalamic tract, and the archispinothalamic tract.
What happens if you have a unilateral sp: A unilateral spinal cord injury can cause a variety of effects, including hemiplegia, hemiparesis, and paralysis on one side of the body. What happens in he Trigeminal system ?: The trigeminal system is responsible for sensory and motor functions in the face, primarily through the trigeminal nerve, which has three main branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves. These branches supply sensation to different regions of the face, including touch, pain, and temperature. The trigeminal nerve can be affected by various medical conditions, such as trigeminal neuralgia, which can cause intense shooting or jabbing pain in the areas supplied by the trigeminal nerve.
What is phantom pain and why do they thi: Phantom pain is the sensation of pain in a body part that has been amputated or is no longer present. It occurs because the brain continues to receive signals from nerves that once connected to the missing limb, leading to the perception of pain despite the absence of the physical body part.
What happens in endogenous analgesia and: Endogenous analgesia and pain modulation involve the body's natural mechanisms for reducing pain perception. This includes the release of endogenous opioids, such as enkephalins, and the activation of pain-modulating neurotransmitters such as dopamine and serotonin. Endogenous analgesia and pain modulation can be influenced by a variety of factors, including inflammation, injury, and genetics.
What are the examples of endogenous liga: Some examples of endogenous ligands of cannabis include anandamide (N-arachidonoylethanolamine), 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG), and 2-arachidonoylethanolamine (2-AEA).
What is the purpose of the cortex, thala: The purpose of the cortex, thalamus, and limbic system in pain stimuli is to process and transmit nociceptive information to the brain. The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals and is involved in processing nociceptive information before transmitting it to the cortex. The limbic system, including structures like the amygdala and hippocampus, is involved in emotions, memory, and behavior, and receives nociceptive information before transmitting it to the cortex.
What are the effects of endogenous opioi: Endogenous opioids are naturally occurring peptides in the body that play a role in regulating pain, emotion, reward, stress responses, motivation, and autonomic control. They interact with opioid receptors in the central and peripheral nervous systems and interact with other neurotransmitters, including the endocannabinoid system. Activation of the endogenous opioid system can lead to addiction and other negative effects.
Examples of acute pain \u2026: Acute pain is characterized by a sudden onset and typically lasts from a few minutes to less than six months. Examples of acute pain include pain caused by injury, surgery, illness, or trauma.
Examples of chronic pain\u2026: Some examples of chronic pain include fibromyalgia, chronic back pain, chronic neck pain, and chronic headaches.
What is hyperalgesia ?: Hyperalgesia is a condition characterized by an increased sensitivity to pain, where stimuli that typically do not cause pain can cause severe discomfort. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including injury, opioid use, or certain medical conditions.
What is the gate theory of pain ?: The gate theory of pain proposes that non-painful input (such as light touch or rubbing) can close the 'gates' to painful input, preventing pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system. This theory was developed by Melzack and Wall in 1965 and has been influential in understanding pain perception and treatment.
How is olfaction sensed ?: The sense of smell is sensed through olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs) located in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity. When odorant molecules are inhaled, they dissolve in the mucus lining the nasal cavity and bind to these receptors, triggering a signal that is transmitted to the olfactory bulb, where it interacts with parts of the brain responsible for smell identification, memory, and emotion.
How is taste sensed ?: Taste is sensed through specialized receptors in the mouth, primarily on the tongue. These receptors detect five basic tastes: sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami. When food is ingested, the microvilli in the taste pore collect information from tastants, which are then transmitted to the brain via gustatory nerves. The brain then decodes this information to create the sensation of taste.
What behaviours do taste and smell play: Taste and smell play a role in a variety of behaviors, including appetite, food choice, and food intake. Smell is primarily responsible for cueing us to eat certain foods, while taste plays a role in determining the quality of the food we eat. Together, these senses play a significant role in shaping our eating habits and preferences.
What is the dominant sense in humans ?: The dominant sense in humans is sight.
What is hypogeusia and ageusia ?: Hypogeusia refers to a partial loss of taste sensation, while ageusia refers to a complete loss of taste sensation.
What is hyposmia and anosmia ?: Hyposmia is a partial loss of smell, while anosmia is a complete loss of smell.
What are the detection threshold holds f: The detection threshold for salt, sugar, acids, and alkaloids varies depending on the individual and the specific substance being tested. It is important to note that sensory thresholds can vary depending on the individual and the specific substance being tested.
What are the 5 basic tastes ?: The five basic tastes are sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.
Why is spicy or minty not classified as: Spicy and minty sensations are not classified as tastes because they are not processed by the taste buds in the mouth. Instead, they are processed by the somatosensory system, which is responsible for touch, temperature, and other sensations.
Other than taste what other factors cont: Other factors that contribute to taste sensation include the size and shape of the molecules in the food, their hydrophobicity, and their stereoisomerization. These factors can influence the perception of different tastes, such as bitterness, sourness, saltiness, and sweetness.
What are the 3 different papillae ?: The three main types of papillae on the tongue are the circumvallate, fungiform, and filiform papillae. Circumvallate papillae are the largest and contain the most taste buds, while fungiform papillae are scattered across the surface of the tongue and also contain taste buds.
Describe circumvallate papillae: Circumvallate papillae are the largest of the four types of papillae on the human tongue. They are located at the junction of the oral and pharyngeal parts of the tongue, and are responsible for taste perception. These papillae receive special afferent taste input from the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), and are responsible for detecting various tastes, including sweet, sour, bitter, and salty.
Describe foliate papillae: Foliate papillae are vertical folds located on the posterolateral sides of the tongue, just anterior to the palatoglossal arch of the fauces. They are covered by a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and contain taste buds, which are involved in the sensation of taste. These papillae play a role in detecting various tastes, including salty, bitter, sour, sweet, and savory.
Describe fungiform papillae: Fungiform papillae are knoblike projections on the tongue, primarily at the anterior margin, including the tip. They are interspersed among filiform papillae and are involved in the sensation of taste, containing taste buds that detect various flavors such as salty, bitter, sour, and sweet. These papillae are protected by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium and play a crucial role in gustation.
What are taste buds like ?: Taste buds are specialized sensory organs on the tongue that allow us to perceive different tastes, including sweet, salty, sour, bitter, and umami. They are located in structures called papillae, and each papilla contains several hundred taste buds. Each taste bud synapses with afferent fibers of gustatory nerves, which transmit sensory information to the brain.
How do tastants trigger a transduction c: Tastants trigger a transduction cascade by binding to G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) on the apical surface of taste cells. This binding activates intracellular signaling pathways such as adenylate cyclase, phospholipase C, and adenylyl cyclase, resulting in the generation of action potentials and the transmission of taste information to the brain.
Why are taste buds not true neurons ?: Taste buds are not true neurons because they are specialized epithelial cells that detect taste stimuli and transmit sensory information to the brain via afferent neurons.
Why is the highest sensitivity on the to: The highest sensitivity on the tongue for bitter tastes is due to the presence of taste receptor type 2 (T2R) receptors, which are G protein-coupled receptors that detect a wide range of bitter compounds. These receptors are primarily located in the back of the tongue, and heightened sensitivity to bitter tastes is believed to have evolved as an aversion to bitter substances.
Where is there higher sensitivity for sw: Higher sensitivity for sweet taste is found at the tip of the tongue.
Describe the sensory transduction of tas: Sensory transduction of taste receptor cells involves the conversion of chemical stimuli into electrical and chemical signals. Where do nerves 7, 9 and 10 receive thei: Nerves 7, 9, and 10 receive their innervation from the brainstem.
What is the transduction cascade for sal: The transduction cascade for salty tastants involves the activation of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) and the voltage-activated ATP release channel (CALHM1/3) in taste bud cells. The activation of these channels by salt tastants results in the release of neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine and dopamine.
What is the transduction cascade for sou: The transduction cascade for sour tastants involves the influx of protons (H+) through the apical membrane of taste bud cells, leading to depolarization and the release of neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine and serotonin.
What is the transduction cascade for bit: The transduction cascade for bitter tastants involves the activation of the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) gustducin, which in turn activates the phosphodiesterase phosphodiesterase (PDE) and cyclic nucleotide-gated ion channels (CNGs). This leads to the perception of bitter taste.
What is the transduction cascade for swe: The transduction cascade for sweet tastants involves the activation of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) on the apical surface of taste cells. When sweet tastants bind to these receptors, they activate the G-protein gustducin, which in turn stimulates adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP levels. This increase in cAMP levels leads to the closure of potassium channels, resulting in the sensation of sweetness.
What is the transduction cascade for uma: The transduction cascade for umami tastants involves the activation of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) on the apical surface of taste cells. This activation leads to the activation of phospholipase C- 2, resulting in the production of inositol triphosphate (IP3) and subsequent release of calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum. This increase in intracellular calcium then activates the TRPM5 ion channel, resulting in the sensation of umami taste.
What are the 2 families of GPCRs used in: The two families of GPCRs used in detecting taste are TAS1R and TAS2R.
Explain the central gustatory pathway ?: The central gustatory pathway involves the transmission of taste information from the taste buds on the tongue to the brain. The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) carry taste signals from the tongue and throat to their respective gangliae, where they synapse before sending signals to the brainstem and ultimately to the gustatory cortex. This pathway allows the brain to interpret and perceive specific taste sensations based on the chemical stimuli detected by taste receptors.
What are the functions each of these str: The cortex, hypothalamus, and amygdala all play a role in taste processing. What percentage of human genome are invo: The percentage of human genome involved with olfaction varies depending on the species. However, it is estimated that about 1% of the human genome is involved in olfaction.

Give examples of neurodegenerative disor: Neurodegenerative disorders include Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), frontotemporal dementia, and spinocerebellar ataxia.
What are the main indications of neurode: Neurodegenerative disorders are characterized by the progressive loss of specific groups of neurons, leading to symptoms such as cognitive decline, motor dysfunction, and loss of function. What is the most common neurodegenerativ: The most common neurodegenerative disorder is Alzheimer's disease.
Define dementia:: Dementia is an umbrella term for a range of neurological conditions that cause a decline in cognitive functioning, affecting memory, thinking, language, and reasoning to the extent that it interferes with daily life. It is characterized by symptoms such as memory loss, difficulty in thinking clearly, and changes in behavior. Alzheimer's disease is one of the most common types of dementia.
Why are the pathological markers of AD?: The pathological markers of Alzheimer's disease (AD) include the accumulation of amyloid-beta (A) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) in the brain, as well as neuroinflammation and oxidative stress. These pathological changes contribute to the neurodegeneration and cognitive decline associated with AD.
What are the pathological markers of PD?: The pathological markers of Parkinson's disease (PD) include the death of dopamine-producing neurons in the Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNpc), the presence of Lewy bodies (LBs) in the brain, and the depletion of dopamine neurotransmitters.
What are the pathological markers of PSP: The pathological markers of Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) include the presence of neuronal and glial inclusions composed of fibrillar pathological tau protein.
What are the pathological markers of CBG: The pathological markers of corticobasal ganglionic degeneration (CBGD) include neuronal and glial (astrocytic) plaques, tau threads, and focal neuronal loss in the neocortex and substantia nigra.
What are the pathological markers of Hun: The pathological markers of Huntington's disease (HD) include the production of mutant huntingtin (mHTT) protein, neuronal degeneration, and involuntary motor symptoms such as chorea, dystonia, and ataxia. What are the pathological markers of pic: The pathological markers of Pick's disease are spherical tau inclusions, which are hyperphosphorylated three-repeat tau protein. What was PD first described as ?: Parkinson's disease (PD) was first described by Dr. James Parkinson in 1817 as a "shaking palsy."
What does PD cause ?: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects the motor system. It is characterized by the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, a region of the brain that controls movement. This loss leads to a range of symptoms, including tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. The exact cause of PD is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Do patients normally die form PD and wha: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) typically have a normal or near-normal life expectancy. However, as the disease progresses, there is a higher risk of complications such as heart disease, stroke, and infections.
What are the main symptoms of Parkinson: The main symptoms of Parkinson disease are tremor (shaking), slowness of movement (bradykinesia), rigidity (stiffness), and postural instability (balance problems).
What do Parkinson\u2019s patients do to: People with Parkinson's disease may use various strategies to help initiate movements, such as swaying from side to side, taking larger steps, or using visual or auditory cues. Additionally, some people with Parkinson's may invent their own strategies or seek help from a healthcare professional.
What are the pathological effects of Par: The pathological effects of Parkinson's disease are the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor. Additionally, the disease is characterized by the accumulation of -synuclein-containing protein aggregates, known as Lewy bodies, in the brain, which can cause cognitive deficits and other non-motor symptoms.
What are the causes of Parkinson\u2019s: The exact cause of Parkinson's disease is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Mutations in the GBA gene, which encodes the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase, are the most common cause of Parkinson's disease. Other genetic and environmental factors, such as exposure to toxins or certain medications, may also contribute to the development of Parkinson's disease.
What things have caused associated disor: The exact cause of Parkinson's disease is still not fully understood, but genetic mutations in the GBA gene, oxidative stress, and environmental toxins have been implicated in the disease's pathogenesis.
What happens to the pathways in Parkinso: In Parkinson's disease, the pathways involved in dopaminergic neuron degeneration are disrupted due to the accumulation of misfolded proteins, such as -synuclein, in the substantia nigra. What happens when light hits the cornea: When light hits the cornea and refracts, it bends or bends back on itself, allowing it to focus on the retina. This process is called refractivity and is crucial for vision.

What is hyperopia ?: Hyperopia, also known as farsightedness, is a refractive error in the eye that causes blurry vision when looking at objects close up. It is a common eye condition that affects about a third of the population.
What is myopia ?: Myopia, also known as nearsightedness, is a vision condition where light rays focus in front of the retina instead of directly on it, causing blurry vision for distant objects.

What is the pigment in rods called and w: The pigment in rods is called rhodopsin. The three types of cones are L-opsin (red), M-opsin (green), and S-opsin (blue).

Why is colour blindness more common in m: Color blindness is more common in men than women due to the X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. What is trichromatic vision ?: Trichromatic vision, also known as trichromacy, refers to the ability of humans and some other animals to perceive color through three independent channels, which are derived from three types of cone cells in the retina. What is the receptive field ?: A receptive field is the specific region in the sensory space where a stimulus, such as light, sound, or touch, can influence the activity of a sensory neuron or group of neurons.
