what do the otolith organs detect?: The otolith organs, specifically the utricle and saccule, detect linear accelerations of the head, such as those caused by tilting or translational movements. The utricle senses horizontal movements, while the saccule senses vertical movements.
What are the ionotropic receptors for gl: The ionotropic receptors for glutamate include NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate), AMPA (-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid), and kainate receptors.
How do mGluR2s work at presynaptic neuro: mGluR2s work at presynaptic neurons by inhibiting glutamate release. They are located on the axon shaft and presynaptic boutons and can be activated by agonists or antagonists.
what is the predatory aggression pathway: The predatory aggression pathway of serotonin involves the dorsal raphe nucleus and the ventral hippocampus, where serotonin plays a crucial role in regulating impulsive and aggressive behavior.
What is fenfluramine used for and why ?: Fenfluramine is primarily used for the treatment of seizures associated with Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It was previously used as an appetite suppressant for weight loss but was discontinued due to cardiovascular toxicity.
What is the general structure and functi: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are ligand-gated ion channels that are activated by the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. The receptor consists of an extracellular domain that binds to acetylcholine, four transmembrane domains, and a cytoplasmic domain. When acetylcholine binds to the receptor, it activates the ion channel, allowing the passage of cations such as Na+ and Ca2
what is the link between serotonin and s: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating the sleep-wake cycle. It is primarily produced in the dorsal raphe nucleus, where it plays a role in regulating both the onset and duration of sleep. Serotonin also interacts with other neurotransmitters, such as dopamine, to influence sleep onset and duration.
How are frequencies below 200Hz encoded: Frequencies below 200Hz are encoded by the auditory system using a temporal code, where neurons fire in phase with sound pressure changes. This method allows the auditory system to represent low-frequency sounds effectively.
Why is serotonin called serotonin ?: Serotonin is called serotonin because it was first discovered in serum, which is the fluid that circulates in the body. It was originally called serum tonic, but was later shortened to serotonin.
What are th effects of noradrenaline rel: Noradrenaline is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in the central nervous system (CNS). It is involved in various cognitive processes such as vigilance, attention, learning, and memory. It also plays a role in regulating body temperature and blood pressure.
What happens when benzodiazepines bind t: When benzodiazepines bind to GABAa receptors, they enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA by promoting chloride ion influx and neuronal hyperpolarization. This results in anxiolytic, sedative, and anticonvulsant effects.
What type of receptor is 5-HT3 ?: The 5-HT3 receptor, also known as the 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) type 3 receptor, is a cation-selective ligand-gated ion channel that belongs to the Cys-loop superfamily of receptors.
Where are alpha-3 beta-4 acetylcholine r: Alpha-3 beta-4 acetylcholine receptors ( 34 nAChRs) are primarily located in the autonomic nervous system, including the adrenal medulla, hypothalamus, and hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis.
Is MAO-A or MAO-B more effective at meta: MAO-A is more effective at metabolizing serotonin (5-HT) compared to MAO-B, and it is present in serotonin neurones.
What is the indirect pathway from the pr: The indirect pathway from the primary motor cortex to spinal cortex involves a complex network of neurons that travels through the brainstem and basal ganglia before reaching the spinal cord.
Where is serotonin present ?: Serotonin is primarily present in the central nervous system (CNS) and the gastrointestinal tract. It is synthesized in the raphe nuclei of the brainstem and enterochromaffin cells of the intestinal mucosa.
What is a major subcortical input to are: One major subcortical input to area 6 is from the ventral lateral nucleus of the dorsal thalamus.
Which acetylcholine receptors are more p: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are more prominent in the brain compared to muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChRs).
What is the structure of the glycine rec: The structure of the glycine receptor is a pentameric anion channel that is permeable to chloride ions. It is composed of two alpha subunits ( 1-4) and three beta subunits ( 1-3). The predominant subunit stoichiometry in native glycine receptors is 4 alpha subunits.
What happens when the stereocillia move: Stereocilia are mechanosensing organelles found on the surface of hair cells in the inner ear. When they move away from the kinocilium, the tension on the tip-link filaments decreases, allowing non-specific ion channels to open, allowing ions to flow into the hair cell and generating an electrical signal.
What is the purpose of the outer hair ce: The purpose of the outer hair cells in the cochlea is to pre-amplify sound waves and transmit them to the inner hair cells, which convert them into electrical signals for the auditory nerve.
What is the corticospinal tract ?: The corticospinal tract, also known as the pyramidal tract, is a major pathway that carries movement-related information from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord. It is responsible for transmitting motor commands from the brain to the spinal cord, facilitating voluntary movements of the limbs and trunk.
What is teh predatory aggression pathway: Predatory aggression is a type of aggressive behavior in animals that is characterized by purposeful and planned actions without perceived threats. It is often triggered by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus and is distinct from affective aggression, which is triggered by perceived threats.
what are accommodating neurons ?: Accommodating neurons are a type of neuron that exhibit a specific firing pattern in response to depolarizing current pulses. They are characterized by their ability to adapt their firing rate over time during a sustained depolarizing current, which is known as spike-frequency accommodation.
Where are low frequency sounds heard on: Low frequency sounds are heard on the basilar membrane near the apex of the cochlea.
How do metabotropic receptors work ?: Metabotropic receptors, also known as G-protein-coupled receptors, are a class of membrane receptors that mediate a variety of physiological functions. Unlike ionotropic receptors, which form ion channels, metabotropic receptors do not have ion channels as part of their structure. Instead, they activate G-protein-coupled receptors, which in turn activate downstream signaling pathways. Metabotropic receptors are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including cell growth, differentiation, and signaling.
When does neuronal firing= frequency ?: Neuronal firing = frequency refers to the rate at which a neuron elicits an action potential or spiking. It is often measured in Hertz (Hz) and can vary depending on various factors such as the strength and duration of the stimulus, the neuron's refractory period, and the type of neuron.
Where is tonotopy seen for sound frequen: Tonotopy for sound frequencies greater than 200Hz is seen in the primary auditory cortex (A1) and the anterior auditory field (AAF) of the auditory cortex. These areas exhibit a progressive change in best frequency (BF) along the anteromedial-posterolateral axis, reflecting the mechanical properties of the cochlea.
How do D2 like receptors work ?: D2-like receptors work by inhibiting the enzyme adenylate cyclase through their G-protein-coupled receptors. This leads to decreased levels of cAMP and increased levels of dopamine in the brain.
What is the stretch reflex ?: The stretch reflex is a type of reflex in which a muscle contracts in response to being stretched. It is primarily mediated by muscle proprioceptors, which detect changes in muscle length or velocity. This reflex plays a crucial role in maintaining proper posture and ensuring stability during movement.
In knocked out mice where are the m2rece: M2 muscarinic receptors are expressed in various tissues, including the brain, spinal cord, and airway smooth muscle. They play a role in analgesia, learning and memory, and the regulation of body temperature. M2 receptor knockout mice exhibit deficits in passive avoidance and working memory, suggesting a critical role for these receptors in cognitive processes.
Where is acetylcholine present in the PN: Acetylcholine is present in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) at neuromuscular junctions and synapses in the ganglia of the visceral motor system.
How does cocaine work ?: Cocaine works by blocking the reuptake of dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine in the brain. This leads to increased levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which in turn stimulates the reward center of the brain, causing feelings of euphoria and arousal.
In knocked out mice where are the m3 rec: In knocked out mice, M3 receptors are expressed in the trachea and bronchi, where they play a role in airway smooth muscle contraction and mucus secretion. Their function is to mediate the effects of acetylcholine on airway smooth muscle contraction and mucus secretion, which are characteristics of asthma.
What 2nd messenger system does norepinep: Norepinephrine uses the cyclic AMP (cAMP) second messenger system.
what the process that occurs when the he: When the head angle changes or accelerates, a force is exerted on the otoconia, which are tiny crystals of calcium carbonate in the otolith organs. This force helps the vestibular system detect changes in head position and motion. The resulting signals contribute to balance and spatial orientation.
What is the link between serotonin and c: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating circadian rhythms. The circadian nuclear receptor REV-ERB in the dorsal raphe nucleus regulates tryptophan hydroxylase 2 (Tph2), the enzyme that synthesizes serotonin (5-HT). Disruptions in this system can lead to altered circadian rhythms and mood disorders such as depression.
Which 2 areas of the brain are dopaminer: The two areas of the brain where dopaminergic cell bodies are clearly visible are the substantia nigra pars compacta and the ventral tegmental area.
What are the subunits for nAChR in muscl: The subunits for nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) in muscle are 1, 1, 1, 1, and 2. These subunits form a pentamer with the stoichiometry 2.
From rat spinal cord what is the structu: Glycine receptors from the rat spinal cord are heteropentameric chloride-permeable ion channels that are similar in structure to GABAA receptors. They are composed of a combination of three to four alpha () subunits and one beta () subunit, with a predominant subunit stoichiometry of 4:1.
In knocked out mice where are the m5 rec: The muscarinic acetylcholine receptor subtype 5 (M5R) is primarily expressed in the substantia nigra and ventral tegmental areas of the brain. Its function is to mediate acetylcholine-induced vasodilation in the cerebral vasculature and modulate dopaminergic transmission.
What is the middle level of sensory feed: The middle level of sensory feedback to the motor hierarchy is referred to as the'motor program'. This level integrates sensory information and creates a pattern of neural activity necessary for executing desired movements.
What are the different families of neuro: There are several families of neuropeptides, including the opioid family, tachykinin family, neuropeptide Y family, and neuropeptide P family.
What amino acid can be converted into se: The amino acid that can be converted into serotonin is L-tryptophan. It is an essential amino acid that must be obtained from dietary sources as the body cannot produce it on its own. The conversion process involves two steps: first, tryptophan is hydroxylated to 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) by tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH), and then 5-HTP is decarboxylated to serotonin by aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase (AADC).
What is the crossed extensor reflex ?: The crossed extensor reflex is a protective spinal reflex that involves the withdrawal of a limb from a painful stimulus while simultaneously activating the extensor muscles of the opposite limb to maintain balance.
What are kainate receptors important for: Kainate receptors are important for a variety of physiological processes, including neurotransmitter release, synaptic transmission, and neuronal excitability. They play a role in both excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission, and have been implicated in various neurological disorders such as epilepsy and Parkinson's disease.
What happens to dopamine once it\u2019s: Once dopamine is released, it binds to dopamine receptors on neighboring neurons, influencing their activity and signaling pathways. This process plays a crucial role in various functions, including reward processing, motivation, and learning.
what do the semicircular canals?: The semicircular canals are three tiny tubes located in the inner ear that play a crucial role in regulating balance and sensing head position. They are part of the vestibular system and are filled with fluid that helps detect rotational movements of the head, providing information about body position and balance. Each canal - the anterior, lateral, and posterior - is oriented at roughly right angles to the others, enabling the detection of movements along three different planes.
What is vigabatrin used to treat ?: Vigabatrin is primarily used to treat infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures in children who have not responded to other treatments. It may also be used off-label for other conditions, such as migraines and neuropathic pain.
What happens when the basilar membrane m: When the basilar membrane moves upward, it causes the tectorial membrane to shear the tips of the stereocilia away from the modiolus, leading to an excitatory response in the hair cells.
what acceleration is detected by the oto: The otolith organs detect linear acceleration, while the semicircular canals detect angular acceleration.
what happens to movements when the activ: When the activity in the direct pathway in the basal ganglia is increased, it generally results in increased motor output. This is because the direct pathway is responsible for coordinating the activity of other motor neurons, such as the motor cortex and the spinal cord, to produce a coordinated movement. In contrast, the indirect pathway is responsible for coordinating the activity of other motor neurons, such as the motor cortex and the spinal cord, to produce a coordinated movement. Therefore, when the activity in the direct pathway in the basal ganglia is increased, it results in increased motor output.
What makes up the striatum ?: The striatum is made up of the caudate nucleus, the putamen, and the ventral striatum, which includes the nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle.
What does the middle ear do ?: The middle ear transmits sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane (eardrum) to the cochlea in the inner ear.
What can excessive dopamine cause ?: Excessive dopamine can cause a variety of symptoms, including insomnia, grandiose thinking, racing thoughts, and impulsivity. It can also be associated with certain mental health disorders, such as depression and anxiety.
Where are m2 acetylcholine receptor?: The M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (M2R) is primarily expressed in the central nervous system, particularly in the brain and spinal cord.
when does serotonin suppress appetite?: Serotonin suppresses appetite by influencing hunger signals and enhancing feelings of satiety. Low levels of serotonin can lead to increased appetite and weight gain.
What groups make up serotonin ?: Serotonin is an indoleamine neurotransmitter that is derived from the amino acid tryptophan through a two-step process. First, tryptophan is converted to 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) through hydroxylation. Then, 5-HTP is decarboxylated to form serotonin.
What is the lowest level of sensory feed: The lowest level of sensory feedback to the motor hierarchy is the spinal cord.
What does sarin gas do ?: Sarin gas is a highly toxic organophosphorus nerve agent that can cause severe health effects, including death, within minutes of exposure. It works by inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which is responsible for deactivating nerve-signaling at neuromuscular junctions. This inhibition prevents muscle relaxation, leading to symptoms such as seizures, paralysis, and difficulty breathing. Exposure to sarin can be lethal even at very low concentrations, with death occurring within one to ten minutes after direct inhalation of a lethal dose.
What does hemicolinium do to cholinergic: Hemicolinium blocks the reuptake of choline by the high-affinity choline transporter, which is the rate-limiting step in acetylcholine synthesis. This results in increased levels of acetylcholine available for cholinergic transmission.
Describe the MAO catabolism pathway for: The MAO catabolism pathway for dopamine involves two enzymes: monoamine oxidase (MAO) and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT). MAO catalyzes the oxidative deamination of dopamine to produce 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetaldehyde, which is further converted to homovanillic acid (HVA) by aldehyde dehydrogenase.
What is cocaine ?: Cocaine is a highly addictive stimulant drug derived from the leaves of the coca plant, primarily grown in Bolivia, Peru, and Colombia. It produces intense euphoria and has a high potential for addiction, affecting the brain's reward system by blocking the reuptake of neurotransmitters like dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine.
What does the frequency of sound refer t: The frequency of sound refers to the number of back-and-forth vibrations of particles per unit of time, as well as the number of compressions or rarefactions that pass a given point per unit of time. It is expressed in cycles per second or Hertz (Hz), where a higher frequency corresponds to a higher pitch and a lower frequency corresponds to a lower pitch.
What does the round windows do ?: I'm sorry, but I don't have enough context to provide a specific answer to your question. Could you please provide more information?
where are the hair cells in the semicirc: The hair cells in the semicircular canals are located within the ampulla of each canal. They are covered by a gelatinous structure called the cupula, which deflects in response to the movement of endolymph when the head rotates. This deflection stimulates the hair cells, sending signals to the brain about head position and movement.
What is substance P ?: Substance P is an undecapeptide (11 amino acids long) and a neuropeptide, belonging to the tachykinin family of neuropeptides. It is primarily involved in pain perception, but also has a wide range of effects in nausea, stress responses, and emotional behavior. Excess levels of substance P can lead to various diseases, highlighting its importance in both normal and pathological processes.
Where is dopamine within neurons ?: Dopamine is primarily found within neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It is packaged into small vesicles and is ready for release when the appropriate signal is received.
How does the basilar membrane move ?: The basilar membrane in the cochlea moves as a traveling wave in response to sound stimuli. Different parts of the membrane move in response to different frequencies of sound, with the base of the membrane vibrating at high frequencies and the apex vibrating at low frequencies. This allows the cochlea to detect and process different frequencies of sound.
What extra molecule does glutamate have: Glutamate has an extra methylene group compared to aspartate.
What is the affective aggression pathway: Affective aggression is a type of aggressive behavior that is characterized by strong emotional responses and retaliatory behavior. It is primarily mediated by the amygdala, prefrontal cortex, and hypothalamus.
How many spiral ganglion cells does a si: A single inner hair cell typically synapses onto approximately 20 spiral ganglion cells.
Is tyrosine an essential or non essentia: Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid, meaning that the human body can synthesize it from another amino acid called phenylalanine.
What is the subunit diversity like in GA: GABAa receptors exhibit significant subunit diversity, with 19 genes encoding different subunits (1-6, 1-3, 1-3,,,,, and 1). This diversity allows for the formation of numerous receptor types with distinct pharmacological and physiological properties, contributing to the complexity of inhibitory signaling in the brain.
What is the organ of corti ?: The organ of Corti is the receptor organ for hearing located in the cochlea of the inner ear. It is named after Italian anatomist Alfonso Corti, who first described it in 1851.
When are peptides referred to as neuromo: Peptides are referred to as neuromodulators when they are released from neurons in the central nervous system and affect groups of neurons or effector cells with the appropriate receptors. They may not be released at synaptic sites, often act through second messengers, and can produce long-lasting effects.
How much more positive is the endolymph,: The endolymph is approximately 80-120 mV more positive than the perilymph due to its higher concentration of positively charged ions, particularly potassium ions, compared to the sodium-rich perilymph.
what are phased neurons ?: Phased neurons refer to neurons that exhibit synchronization of their oscillatory phases, particularly in relation to gamma and theta oscillations. This synchronization is believed to facilitate communication between different brain regions and support cognitive functions, such as working memory and long-term memory.
What is the difference about the release: The release of small molecule neurotransmitters and neuropeptides is different. Small molecule neurotransmitters are synthesized and packaged into vesicles within the presynaptic terminal for rapid release, while neuropeptides are synthesized in the cell body and then transported to the axon terminal, where they are stored in larger vesicles. This allows for slower release and modulation of ongoing neuronal activity.
How are neuropeptides synthesised ?: Neuropeptides are synthesized in the neuronal cell body from large precursor proteins called prepropeptides. These precursors are then processed in the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi apparatus, where they undergo cleavage and posttranslational modifications to yield active neuropeptides.
What is the reverse stretch reflex ?: The reverse stretch reflex, also known as the autogenic inhibition reflex, is a reflex action mediated by the Golgi tendon organs. When these organs are stimulated by a prolonged stretch, they cause the stretched muscle to relax. This reflex is the opposite of the myotatic reflex, which causes muscle contraction in response to stretching.
What happens when the basilar membrane m: When the basilar membrane moves downwards, the tectorial membrane shears the tips of the stereocilia toward the modiolus. This causes an inhibitory response in the hair cell, leading it to hyperpolarize or enter a refractory phase.
How do alpha-1 receptors work ?: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptors ( 1-ARs) are G protein-coupled receptors that primarily bind to the Gq heterotrimeric G protein. They are involved in neurotransmission and regulate the sympathetic nervous system through binding and activation of norepinephrine and epinephrine. There are three subtypes of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors ( 1A,  1B, and  1C).
What are the 2 mechanisms for horizOntal: The two mechanisms for horizontal sound localisation are interaural time differences (ITD) and interaural level differences (ILD).
Which layer of m1 does the activation of: The activation of lower motor neurons originates in layer 5 of the primary motor cortex (M1).
What is the middle level of the central: The middle level of the central motor system consists of the motor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
Why is it important to have sufficient t: It is important to have sufficient tryptophan in your diet because it is an essential amino acid that the body cannot produce on its own. It is a precursor for serotonin, a neurotransmitter that regulates mood, anxiety, and sleep. Additionally, tryptophan is a precursor for niacin, a vitamin B3 that supports immune function.
What is the function of lysergic acid di: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a psychedelic drug that alters perception, thought, and emotion. It primarily acts as an agonist at serotonin receptors, particularly the 5-HT2A receptor, and has been studied for its potential therapeutic effects in treating anxiety, depression, and other mental health disorders.
What is the Mesolimbic pathway ?: The mesolimbic pathway is a neuronal pathway that consists of dopaminergic projections from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the nucleus accumbens (NAc). It is often referred to as the reward pathway and plays a crucial role in motivation and reward-related behavior.
What happens is the main purpose of the: The main purpose of auditory receptors (hair cells) is to convert mechanical stimuli, such as sound vibrations, into electrical signals that can be transmitted to the brain.
Describe the structure of neuropeptides: Neuropeptides are small protein-like molecules that play a variety of roles in the nervous system. They are typically composed of a single chain of amino acids, typically ranging from 3 to over 100 residues. Neuropeptides are synthesized in neurons and released from dense core vesicles, which can be found in the synaptic cleft, cell body, and axon. Their structure and function are highly variable, allowing them to play critical roles in a wide range of physiological processes.
How do beta- receptors work ?: Beta-receptors are a type of adrenergic receptor that are activated by catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. Activation of beta receptors leads to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, which mediates their effects on various physiological processes such as heart rate, blood pressure, and bronchodilation.
Where are the major cholinergic clusters: The major cholinergic clusters in the CNS are located in the hippocampal complex, olfactory bulb, cerebral cortex, and amygdala.
what did the organs of balance originate: The organs of balance, known as the vestibular system, originated from the otolith organs and ampulla spaces within the inner ear. These structures contain sensory hair cells that detect head movements and transmit this information to the brain, helping to maintain balance and spatial orientation.
What is the lowest level of the central: The lowest level of the central motor system is the spinal cord.
After the release of serotonin what happ: After the release of serotonin, it can either be taken up by serotonin receptors on the postsynaptic neuron or degraded by the enzyme monoamine oxidase.
What is sumatriptan ?: Sumatriptan is a medication used to treat migraine headaches and cluster headaches. It works by narrowing blood vessels in the head and reducing pain signals to the brain. Sumatriptan can be taken orally, intranasally, or by subcutaneous injection.
What is an example of an antagonist for: An example of an antagonist for NMDA receptors is MK-801, also known as dizocilpine.
what makes up the semicircular canals?: The semicircular canals are three loop-shaped structures in the inner ear that play a crucial role in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. They are part of the vestibular system and are filled with fluid called endolymph. The lateral semicircular canal detects angular acceleration, the anterior semicircular canal detects vertical acceleration, and the posterior semicircular canal detects rotational acceleration.
